{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15592,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abies religiosa, commonly known as the sacred fir, prefers moist but well-drained soils. It is important to ensure that the soil does not become waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. During dry periods, especially in the summer, regular watering is necessary to maintain moisture levels. However, it's ideal to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering. In its natural habitat, the sacred fir enjoys cooler, humid conditions, so mimicking these conditions with consistent soil moisture is beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The sacred fir thrives best in locations that receive full sun to partial shade. In its natural habitat, it is accustomed to high elevation forest conditions where sunlight can be more intense but tempered by surrounding canopy. Ideally, plant it where it receives at least four to six hours of sunlight per day. However, in particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the tree from intense sun and heat stress. The balance between sunlight and shade will ensure optimal growth and health for the tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Abies religiosa should be performed with minimal impact, mainly to maintain a healthy structure and remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches. This should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins, allowing the tree to heal and grow over the upcoming season. Excessive pruning can stress the tree, so it's advisable to only prune what is necessary. Avoid cutting into the main trunk or removing the leader, as this can distort the shape and growth habit of the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sacred fir","description":"The sacred fir or Abies religiosa (known as oyamel in Spanish) is a fir native to the mountains of central and southern Mexico (Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt, Sierra Madre del Sur) and western Guatemala. It grows at high altitudes of 2,100–4,100 metres (6,900–13,500 ft) in cloud forests with cool, humid summers and dry winters in most of its habitat regime. In the state of Veracruz, it grows with precipitation all year long. The tree is resistant to regular...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["sacred fir"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Abies religiosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16208,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clematis vitalba, commonly known as Old Man's Beard or Traveller's Joy, requires consistent moisture, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. The soil should be kept evenly moist but well-drained to prevent root rot. It's important to water deeply to encourage deep root development and reduce surface evaporation. In hot weather, provide extra water, but allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. Reduce watering in fall to prepare the plant for its winter dormancy phase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis vitalba thrives in a location that provides full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of sunlight a day to promote abundant flowering. Morning sun with afternoon shade is perfect for hot, sunny climates, as it helps protect the plant from being scorched. Although it is tolerant of more shaded conditions, flowering may be reduced. For optimal health, aim to plant it in a site where the roots are shaded and cool, but the top of the plant can bask in the sun. A mulch or low-growing ground cover can help keep roots cool in hotter regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis vitalba is essential to manage its vigorous growth and encourage flowering. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. This plant blooms on new wood, so you can prune it back hard to a pair of strong buds about 12 inches from the ground. Be sure to remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the year to maintain plant health and shape. Regular pruning also helps to control its size and prevent it from becoming overly invasive in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Old man's beard","description":"Clematis vitalba (also known as old man's beard and traveller's joy) is a shrub of the Ranunculaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Old man's beard"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Clematis vitalba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Chalky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16082,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Berlandiera lyrata, commonly known as Chocolate Flower, prefers moderate watering. It's drought-tolerant once established, making it ideal for dry climates. During the growing season, water deeply once a week. Ensure soil is well-drained as it dislikes overly wet conditions. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Overwatering can lead to root rot. In very hot and dry areas, slightly increase the frequency, but always allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to mimic its natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chocolate Flower thrives in full sun, needing at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. It's well-suited to sunny spots where it can soak up maximum light. Insufficient sunlight can result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. While it tolerates some partial shade, especially in hot climates, full sun exposure ensures vibrant blossoms and a healthy, robust plant. When planting, choose a location with southern or western exposure to maximize sunlight, and avoid placing it in shaded or overly sheltered areas that might limit light access."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berlandiera lyrata is straightforward. Deadheading spent flowers will encourage more blooms and a tidier appearance. After the flowering season, typically in late autumn, cut back the plant by about one-third to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. If it becomes leggy, a stronger prune in early spring will rejuvenate the plant. However, avoid heavy pruning in late fall since it can affect the plant's hardiness over the winter months. Regularly remove any yellowing leaves or stems to keep the plant healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"lyre-leaf greeneyes","description":"Berlandiera lyrata, with the common names chocolate flower, chocolate daisy, or lyreleaf greeneyes, is a North American species of flowering plant in the sunflower family. The common name lyreleaf greeneyes is a reference to the shape of the leaf, which is curved like a lyre and the green disc which is left behind when the ray florets drop off which is thought to look like an eye.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["lyre-leaf greeneyes"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Berlandiera lyrata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15798,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hymenoxys richardsonii, commonly known as Richardson's Bitterweed, is a drought-tolerant plant requiring minimal watering once established. During its initial growth phase, regular watering is necessary to help the roots establish. After establishment, it should be watered only during prolonged dry periods. Overwatering should be avoided as it prefers dry to slightly moist soil conditions. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the plant's roots. It's adapted to arid environments, so letting the topsoil dry out between watering sessions is beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hymenoxys richardsonii thrives in full sunlight, necessitating at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. It is well-suited for open and sunny areas where it can receive abundant sunlight. While it can tolerate some light shade, the plant performs best with ample sun exposure, which encourages robust blooming and healthy growth. In overly shaded conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ideal planting spots mimic its native arid and sunny habitats, ensuring the plant maintains its vibrant characteristics."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hymenoxys richardsonii is generally not demanding but can enhance plant health and aesthetics. Deadheading spent flowers during the blooming season encourages further blooms and prevents the plant from wasting energy on seed production. In early spring, light pruning can shape the plant and remove any dead or damaged foliage, promoting healthier growth. In harsher climates, cutting back after the first frost can help prepare the plant for winter dormancy. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid introducing disease into the wounds created by pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pingue Rubberweed","description":"Hymenoxys richardsonii (common names pingue hymenoxys and pingue rubberweed) is a North American species of plants in the sunflower family. It is widespread across the western United States and western Canada from Arizona, New Mexico, and western Texas north as far as Alberta and Saskatchewan.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Pingue Rubberweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Hymenoxys richardsonii"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to ensure that the soil does not dry out completely between waterings, especially during its growing season. However, while the plant enjoys moisture, avoid waterlogging the soil as this can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature, which benefits the plant's root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lyonia ligustrina thrives in a range of sunlight conditions, from partial shade to full sun. In shaded areas, the plant may grow more slowly and produce fewer flowers but will still maintain a healthy appearance. Selecting the right balance based on your climate ensures optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lyonia ligustrina is typically done to maintain its shape and to remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This timing helps you see the branch structure more clearly, allowing focused pruning. You can lightly prune to manage size or deadhead spent flowers to promote new growth. Make clean cuts just above a bud or branch node. Regular pruning helps encourage fuller growth habits and improves air circulation through the shrub."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"He-huckleberry","description":"Lyonia ligustrina is a species of flowering plant in the heath family known by the common names maleberry and he-huckleberry. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14703,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amanita flavoconia, commonly known as the yellow patches mushroom, is not typically cultivated or cared for like a houseplant, as it is a wild and toxic mushroom. Therefore, it does not require watering. In its natural habitat, it grows in moist, forested areas where it receives adequate moisture from the environment and surrounding soil. If observed in the wild, there is no need to provide additional water, as this could disrupt the natural ecosystem."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amanita flavoconia thrives in shaded, forested areas and does not require direct sunlight. It usually grows under the cover of trees where sunlight is filtered and indirect. The dappled light conditions of a forest floor provide an ideal setting for this mushroom. Direct sunlight may dry out the mushroom and affect its environment, so it should be left to grow naturally in its preferred low-light conditions. Leaving it undisturbed ensures the balance of its natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Amanita flavoconia since it is a mushroom and not a plant that benefits from such maintenance. In natural settings, mushrooms do not require human intervention for growth. Handling or consuming Amanita flavoconia is not advisable due to its toxic nature, so it should be left to decompose naturally in its environment. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. During the plant's active growth period in spring and summer, provide additional watering, while in winter, reduce the frequency. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering needs. Monitor the plant for signs of dehydration such as wilting leaves, adjusting your watering habits accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus argutus grows best in full sun to partial shade, with a preference for full sunlight which aids in the production of sweet, plentiful berries. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure healthy growth and fruit production. While it can tolerate some shade, be mindful that reduced sunlight can lead to fewer and sourer berries. If planted in a shaded area, ensure it's still bright and no larger plants block too much light, as insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced yields."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus argutus is essential to maintain its shape, health, and fruit production. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased canes at their base. Thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation, which helps prevent disease. Once the plant has finished fruiting, cut back the floricanes (second-year canes) to ground level as they will not fruit again. Maintain the primocanes (first-year canes) for next year’s fruit. Regular pruning encourages vigorous new growth and maximizes berry yield."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sawtooth blackberry","description":"Rubus argutus is a North American species of prickly bramble in the rose family. It is a perennial native to the eastern and south-central United States from Florida to Texas, Missouri, Illinois, and Maine. Common names are sawtooth blackberry or tall blackberry because of its habit of growing up to 2 meters (80 inches) in height.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["sawtooth blackberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Cane borers","Fungal diseases","Mildew"],"propagation":["Root division","Stem cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rubus argutus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14902,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asclepias subverticillata, also known as horsetail milkweed, thrives in well-drained soils and typically requires minimal watering once established. It's drought-tolerant, making it ideal for xeriscaping. During the establishment phase, water the plant moderately to ensure strong root development. Allow the soil to dry between watering sessions to prevent root rot, which this plant is susceptible to if overwatered. In areas with substantial rainfall, supplemental watering might not be necessary. Adjust the watering frequency based on season and humidity, watering less during cooler months when growth is slower."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asclepias subverticillata prefers full sun exposure for optimal growth and blooming. It should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight daily. In partial shade, the plant may still survive but will display reduced flowering and potentially leggier growth. Full sunlight ensures robust flowering and healthy foliage. If grown indoors or in shaded areas, supplemental lighting might be necessary to mimic its natural habitat conditions. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade might protect it from scorching but ensure it still receives ample morning sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias subverticillata is usually minimal. It's advisable to remove dead or damaged stems at the beginning of spring to encourage healthy new growth. Light pruning can also be done after the flowering season to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to avoid damage and disease transmission. Additionally, cutting back the plant during high growth seasons can help control its spread and maintain its desired size, as it can grow quite vigorously under ideal conditions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"horsetail milkweed","description":"Asclepias subverticillata, also known as whorled milkweed, is a plant found in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["horsetail milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias subverticillata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15593,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acrostichum aureum, commonly known as the golden leather fern, thrives in consistently moist environments. However, ensure the pot has good drainage if kept indoors. Mist the leaves occasionally to maintain humidity, especially in drier environments. Reduce watering during the cooler months, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings while still keeping the overall soil body moist."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acrostichum aureum prefers bright, indirect sunlight. However, prolonged exposure to harsh afternoon sun can scorch the leaves, so it is advisable to provide filtered light or partial shade during these hours. If grown indoors, place it near a window where it receives plenty of diffused light. A position with dappled sunlight, similar to its natural habitat in wetlands under larger trees, will help this plant to flourish."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Acrostichum aureum to remove dead or damaged fronds, which helps maintain its appearance and encourages healthy growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the fronds close to the base. Regularly inspect the plant and remove any yellowing or browning leaves to prevent decay. If your plant is becoming too large for its space, trim back longer fronds to manage its size. Late spring or early summer is generally the best time for heavier pruning as the plant enters its active growing phase."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Leather Fern","description":"Acrostichum aureum, the golden leather fern, is a large species of fern that grows in mangrove swamps and other wet locations. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15003,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex grayi, commonly known as Gray's sedge, prefers consistently moist soil, making regular watering a priority to simulate its natural wetland habitat. Ensure the soil is always damp but not waterlogged to avoid root rot. During dry spells or summer months, increase your watering frequency, though in cooler months, less frequent watering is required. Checking the top inch of the soil—if it's dry—is a good indicator for watering. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and protect the plant's roots. Additionally, consider the plant's location, as exposure to sunlight can increase its water requirements."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex grayi thrives best in conditions of partial to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive around 3-6 hours of morning or late afternoon sun, with some dappled shade during the hottest part of the day. Too much intense sunny exposure could stress the plant, causing leaf scorch. However, in areas with colder climates, more sunlight can be beneficial. If planted indoors or in a shaded garden, ensure that it receives indirect sunlight to support healthy growth. Adjust the plant’s position based on seasonal changes to provide optimal light exposure throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex grayi primarily involves removing dead or damaged foliage to maintain its health and appearance. This can be done at any time during the growing season. For a more thorough tidy-up, you may cut back the entire plant to a height of a few inches above the ground in early spring before new growth begins. This will encourage fresh growth and retain the plant’s neat appearance. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent disease, and remove cut foliage to keep the area tidy and reduce the chance of pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gray's sedge","description":"Carex grayi, commonly known as Gray's sedge, is a species of flowering plant in the Cyperaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Gray's sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex grayi"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15994,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aethusa cynapium, commonly known as Fool's Parsley, prefers moderately moist soil. It is important to ensure that the plant does not dry out completely, especially during hot and dry periods. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. A good practice is to water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During rainy seasons, natural rainfall might suffice, but additional watering may be necessary in drier or more arid climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aethusa cynapium thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish. In regions with very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the plant from wilting under extreme heat. Too much shade can result in leggy growth and poor flowering. When planting, select a location where the plant will receive the appropriate amount of light. Adjust its position as needed to ensure optimal sunlight exposure for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aethusa cynapium is generally not necessary as this is an annual plant that doesn't require shaping or size control. However, you can deadhead the flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding if you do not want it to spread extensively. This involves cutting off spent flowers before they have the chance to develop seeds. This plant will die back naturally at the end of its growing season, at which point it should be removed from the area if you want to clean up the garden or prevent natural reseeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fool's parsley","description":"Aethusa cynapium (fool's parsley, fool's cicely, or poison parsley) is an annual (rarely biennial) herb in the plant family Apiaceae, native to Europe, western Asia, and northwest Africa. It is the only member of the genus Aethusa. It is related to Hemlock and Water-dropwort, and like them it is poisonous, though less so than hemlock. It has been introduced into many other parts of the world and is a common weed in cultivated ground.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Fool's parsley"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aethusa cynapium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

Deadhead the flowers as they fade and remove any brown or dying leaves to promote new growth and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Regular trimming or pinching back of the stems can stimulate bushier growth and control the plant's height or spread, especially if you are growing it in a limited space or a container. Prune at the beginning of the growing season and as needed thereafter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple Cleome","description":"Cleome rutidosperma, commonly known as fringed spider flower or purple cleome, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Cleome of the family Cleomaceae, native to tropical Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16305,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dicranum polysetum, a moss, requires a moist but not waterlogged environment. It thrives in conditions with high humidity, so regular misting is beneficial, especially in drier climates or indoors. The substrate should be kept consistently damp, but ensure there is good drainage to prevent waterlogging. Avoid allowing the moss to completely dry out, as this can be detrimental to its health. A good practice is to provide rainwater or distilled water to prevent mineral build-up, as mosses are sensitive to tap water additives."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dicranum polysetum thrives in low to medium indirect light conditions. Direct sunlight can cause the moss to dry out and become brown, so it’s best kept in shaded areas, like under tree canopies or in shadowed parts of a terrarium. For indoor settings, a north or east-facing window is ideal to provide adequate but gentle light. If the moss appears to be sparse or losing vibrancy, it might need slightly more indirect light, but always avoid intense or direct sun exposure to maintain its lush green state."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dicranum polysetum is minimal but helps maintain its appearance. Regularly inspect the moss and remove debris, dead or discolored leaves gently by hand or with tweezers. Pruning helps keep the moss carpet tidy and encourages new growth. Avoid cutting the healthy parts aggressively, as mosses grow slower compared to other plants. If moss carpets become too dense or compact, gently tease apart sections to improve air circulation, which helps prevent mold and disease build-up in dense clusters."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Waxyleaf Moss","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Waxyleaf Moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Dicranum polysetum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly during its first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system, and reduce the frequency afterward. During prolonged dry periods, additional watering may help maintain its vibrant appearance, although it can survive with minimal watering. Be careful not to overwater, as it may lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is well-drained, as standing water is detrimental. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and moderate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Baldwin's ironweed thrives in full sun to partial shade, though it performs best with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, reduced sunlight can lead to fewer blooms and a leggy growth habit. To support sturdy stems and vibrant blooms, plant Vernonia baldwinii in a location with ample sunlight exposure. If planted in a shadier spot, it may require support to prevent flopping. For optimal blooming and growth, choose a site that receives generous sunshine throughout the day. Exposure to morning and afternoon sun is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernonia baldwinii is mostly about maintaining its shape and encouraging a bushier growth habit. Cut back the plant in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems from the previous season’s growth. Doing so will stimulate new growth. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can prolong the blooming period. In late fall or early spring, it’s a good idea to cut the plant back to about 6 inches above the ground to tidy up its appearance and promote healthy growth. This perennial generally does well without extensive pruning beyond these basic practices."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Ironweed","description":"Vernonia baldwinii, the western ironweed or Baldwin's ironweed, is a perennial herb native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Western Ironweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vernonia baldwinii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to maintain a consistent watering schedule to keep the soil moist, especially during dry periods or extended droughts. However, avoid waterlogging the soil as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. In well-drained soils, water deeply but less frequently to encourage deep root development. During periods of natural rainfall, supplemental watering may not be necessary unless conditions are exceptionally dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diodia virginiana thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It performs best with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily, which promotes compact, healthy growth and abundant flowering. In areas with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching and help retain soil moisture. Although it can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. Balancing sunlight exposure ensures optimal health and aesthetic appeal for the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Diodia virginiana isn't typically necessary unless you are looking to control its spread or to improve its appearance. It can be pruned back in the late fall or early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems. This plant tends to spread vigorously, so occasional trimming can help manage its growth. Remove any spent or dead flowers to encourage further blooming and to prevent self-seeding, although this plant's resilient nature allows it to recover well from even severe pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"buttonweed","description":"Diodia virginiana is a plant species in the Rubiaceae, common name Virginia buttonweed. It is a spreading, matted perennial with opposite leaves, often mottled because of a virus that attacks the foliage. Flowers are white, cross-shaped with 4 petals. Fruits are green, often floating on water. The species can become a nuisance weed, hard to eradicate because of underground parts that remain behind when you try to pull up the plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["buttonweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Diodia virginiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When watering, ensure the soil is moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, water deeply and less frequently to encourage deep root growth. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In particularly dry periods, you may need to increase the frequency slightly. This can be done throughout the growing season to encourage further flowering and maintain a neat appearance. In late fall or early spring, cut back the plant to about 4-6 inches above the ground to clean up old growth and stimulate new growth in the spring. Avoid heavy pruning during late summer or fall to ensure the plant's energy is focused on overwintering. Regular pruning also helps improve air circulation, reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spotted horse mint","description":"Monarda punctata is a herbaceous plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae, that is native to eastern Canada, the eastern United States and northeastern Mexico. The best time to prune is right after the plant has finished flowering in late spring to early summer, allowing new growth to harden off before winter. Regularly deadheading spent blooms will encourage a tidier appearance and more vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese andromeda","description":"Pieris japonica, the Japanese andromeda or Japanese pieris, is a plant in the heather family, Ericaceae. However, during dormant periods, such as colder months, reduce watering significantly. During the growing season, ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. In drier regions or during periods of drought, increase the frequency of watering. The plant is somewhat tolerant of short dry spells once established but performs best with regular moisture. To conserve moisture and maintain a stable environment for the roots, adding a layer of mulch around the base is beneficial. Reduce watering in late fall and winter as the plant goes dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Callicarpa dichotoma thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal berry production and vibrant foliage, planting in an area that receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day is recommended. In hotter climates, afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. However, in too much shade, the plant may produce fewer berries and have a leggier appearance. A balance between sun and shade will foster healthy growth and abundant berry displays, making it important to consider the plant's sun exposure when selecting its location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Callicarpa dichotoma is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This plant blooms on new wood, so pruning at this time encourages the development of flowering stems. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation and aesthetics. Cut back the plant to about one-third of its size to promote a fuller shape and enhance berry production in the coming season. Light shaping can be done after flowering, but extensive pruning should be saved for the dormant season to prevent loss of berries."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple Beautyberry","description":"Callicarpa dichotoma (common names, Purple Beautyberry or Early Amethyst) is species of beautyberry. They are cultivated as garden trees. The flowers are pink to white. The berries which are small drupes are purple. The fruits grow closely together in large clusters. The fruit provides food for wild life. The berries are bitter and are unfit for culinary use. This species can be found in China, Vietnam, Korea and Japan.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","China","Korea"],"other_name":["Purple Beautyberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Callicarpa dichotoma"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The key to watering this plant is to let the soil dry out completely before watering again. Over-watering can lead to root rot, which is detrimental to its health. During hot, dry periods, you can water more frequently, but always check the soil moisture first. Insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and a leggy appearance. If planting in a garden, choose a location where it will receive unobstructed sunlight. If growing in containers, make sure to position them in a sunny spot to meet the light needs of this sun-loving plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gaillardia pinnatifida is not very demanding, but it can help maintain a tidy appearance and promote more blooms. The best time to prune is in early spring before the plant begins its new growth. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can be done throughout the flowering season to encourage continuous blooming. In late fall, you can cut back the plant to approximately 6 inches above the ground to help it overwinter and encourage healthier growth in the following season. It is important to water it regularly, ensuring the soil stays consistently moist but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as it may lead to root rot. During periods of high heat or dry seasons, increase the frequency of watering to maintain adequate soil moisture. Additionally, ensure good drainage to prevent excess water accumulation around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Shining bedstraw, or Galium concinnum, thrives best in partial to full shade conditions. While it can tolerate some sunlight, it is generally happiest in dappled shade or areas where it receives filtered sunlight throughout the day. Avoid exposing the plant to harsh, direct sunlight for extended periods, as it may cause leaf burn. In natural settings, it often grows under the canopy of trees, which provides the ideal conditions for its growth. Adjust the sunlight exposure based on the plant’s response and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium concinnum generally involves removing dead or yellowing stems and foliage to promote healthy growth and appearance. Since it has a natural clumping habit, pruning is not often required but can be performed in early spring before new growth begins. This helps to encourage a fuller plant. Light trimming may also be done in late summer to keep the plant tidy. Ensure that you use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant and to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"shining bedstraw","description":"Galium concinnum, the shining bedstraw, is a plant species in the Rubiaceae. It is native to the Midwestern United States and central Canada, especially the Great Lakes Region and the Valleys of the Ohio, lower Missouri, and upper Mississippi Rivers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16085,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Betula nana, or the dwarf birch, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soils. It is important to ensure that the soil does not dry out completely, particularly during the warmer months, as this can stress the plant. During the growing season, water the plant adequately to keep the soil moist, but be careful to avoid waterlogging which can lead to root rot. In the winter months, reduce watering slightly, as natural precipitation usually provides sufficient moisture. However, check the soil regularly and water if it becomes too dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Betula nana thrives best in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with very hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. However, too much shade can lead to reduced growth and a less vibrant appearance. Ensure that the plant is not overshadowed by larger plants or structures and that it receives ample light throughout the day for lush foliage and healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Betula nana is typically minimal and mainly for maintaining shape and removing any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is in late winter to early spring when the plant is still dormant. This helps minimize sap loss and allows wounds to heal quickly before the growing season begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts and avoid tearing the bark. Regularly inspect the plant for any crossing branches or overcrowded areas to ensure good air circulation and sunlight penetration."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dwarf Birch","description":"Betula nana, the dwarf birch, is a species of birch in the family Betulaceae, found mainly in the tundra of the Arctic region.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Arctic regions","Northern Europe","Northern Asia"],"other_name":["Dwarf Birch"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Betula nana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Silty"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16805,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlox carolina, commonly known as Carolina phlox, requires regular watering to maintain moist, but not waterlogged soil. It is essential to keep the soil evenly damp, especially during hot, dry periods. However, ensure that the roots do not sit in standing water to prevent root rot. Mulching around the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. During times of regular rainfall, less additional watering may be necessary. Test the soil with your finger - if the top inch is dry, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox carolina thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal blooming. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and prolong blooming. When planting in partial shade, ensure that the plant receives enough light for vibrant flower production. This plant is adaptable to different light conditions but will flower best with sufficient sunlight exposure. Adjust positioning if blooms decline or the plant appears leggy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox carolina involves removing dead or faded flowers to encourage continuous blooming throughout its planting season. This is known as deadheading and should be done regularly. It is also beneficial to cut back the plant in the late fall after blooming has finished or in early spring before new growth begins. This promotes healthy, vigorous growth and helps maintain a neat appearance. When pruning, always use sterilized tools to prevent disease transmission, and cut stems back to the base to encourage bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"thickleaf phlox","description":"Phlox carolina, the thickleaf phlox, is a species of flowering plant in the family Polemoniaceae. It is an herbaceous perennial growing to 1.2 m (4 ft) tall by 45 cm (18 in) wide, with leaves to 13 cm (5 in) long, and purple or pink flowers in summer. The specific epithet carolina refers to its native habitat in the eastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["thickleaf phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Phlox carolina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Cut back the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins, removing any dead or damaged stems. Be cautious not to prune too harshly during blooming, as this might reduce flower production. Use clean, sharp tools to minimize plant stress and the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"purple crownvetch","description":"Securigera varia (synonym Coronilla varia), commonly known as crownvetch or purple crown vetch, is a low-growing legume vine. It has become an invasive species in many states of the US.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Europe","Southwest Asia"],"other_name":["purple crownvetch"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Securigera varia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It requires minimal watering. During the first year after planting, water it regularly to help the roots establish. Once established, water the plant only during prolonged periods of drought. Overwatering should be avoided as it prefers well-drained soils and can suffer if conditions are too moist. Checking the soil moisture level before watering is recommended – if the top few inches of soil are dry, then the plant likely needs watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus oxycedrus thrives in full sunlight and will grow best if it receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate some shade, but full sun promotes denser foliage and better overall health. In less sunny conditions, the plant may become sparse and leggy. The location should have good air circulation to prevent issues like rust disease, which can affect junipers but is less likely in optimal sun conditions. When planting, choose a sunny spot to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prickly juniper does not require frequent pruning to maintain its shape. Pruning is best done in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. It's primarily about removing dead, diseased, or crossing branches to ensure good air circulation and sunlight penetration within the shrub. Light pruning can also be done to shape the plant or control its size. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of disease. Refrain from cutting into old wood as junipers do not regrow from old wood areas."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"western prickly juniper","description":"Juniperus oxycedrus (prickly juniper, prickly cedar, cade juniper and cade (from the French genévrier cade), sharp cedar) is a species of juniper, native across the Mediterranean region from Morocco and Portugal, north to southern France, east to westernmost Iran, and south to Lebanon and Israel, growing on a variety of rocky sites from sea level up to 1600 m elevation. The specific epithet oxycedrus means \"sharp cedar\" and this species may have been the original cedar...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["western prickly juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus oxycedrus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In particularly hot weather, increasing the frequency of watering may be necessary to compensate for rapid evaporation. Conversely, during cooler months, reduce watering accordingly. Always consider the plant's environmental conditions, such as sunlight and humidity, in altering watering schedules."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox cuspidata thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to encourage optimum flowering and development. In hotter regions, providing light afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from becoming stressed or wilted. Insufficient sunlight may lead to poor flowering and leggy growth. Ensure that it is planted in a location that maximizes sunlight exposure while minimizing excessive heat during peak midday sun. Adjustments might be necessary if the plant shows signs of sunburn or too much shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox cuspidata helps promote healthy growth and a tidy appearance. In the early spring, before new growth begins, remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage vigorous growth. During the blooming season, regularly deadhead spent flowers to prolong the blooming period and redirect energy into producing more flowers rather than seeds. After flowering finishes, cutting back the stems by about one-third can promote bushier growth and prevent the plant from looking too leggy. This maintenance helps ensure the plant remains healthy and attractive throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pointed phlox","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["pointed phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phlox cuspidata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Indirect or diffused light is suitable, allowing the fungus to thrive without the risk of dehydration. Maintaining consistent shade will mimic its natural habitat, promoting healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Hapalopilus nidulans since it is a fungus and does not grow in the traditional leafy or woody manner that requires shaping or cutting back. Instead, focus on maintaining a clean environment, as fungi typically thrive when undisturbed. Remove any substrate or surrounding material that may have been contaminated or that might support competing organisms or pests. It’s essential to monitor the growth to ensure any necrotic or discolored areas are addressed by adjusting environmental conditions rather than pruning."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Cinnamon Bracket","description":"Hapalopilus nidulans (also known as Hapalopilus rutilans) is a species of polypore fungus in the family Polyporaceae. This widely distributed species is found on five continents. Maintain a water level that allows the plant to float freely while keeping its roots submerged. Regularly check and change the water to prevent stagnation and ensure appropriate quality. Ideally, allow the water to recirculate or add a small aquarium filter to ensure adequate oxygenation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nymphoides indica prefers indirect, moderate sunlight when placed in aquariums or indoor water gardens. For indoor settings, place the plant near a bright window where it can receive filtered sunlight or use full-spectrum grow lights to mimic natural conditions, encouraging healthy blooming and foliage development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning helps Nymphoides indica maintain its vitality and prevents overcrowding in aquatic setups. Use scissors or plant shears to trim back leaves that appear yellow, damaged, or overgrown to keep the plant looking neat and to encourage healthier new growth. Careful trimming also prevents the plant from overshadowing other aquatic plants if used in a pond or aquarium setting. Be sure to remove any debris from the water after pruning to maintain water quality. Aim to prune the plant every few weeks or as each season changes to keep it in optimal health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Water Snowflake","description":"Nymphoides indica is an aquatic plant in the Menyanthaceae, native to tropical areas around the world. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15998,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agastache scrophulariifolia thrives best with moderate water levels. The key is to maintain a consistently moist soil without letting it become waterlogged. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so good drainage is essential. During the active growing seasons of spring and summer, watering may need to be more regular depending on the environmental conditions, while in fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agastache scrophulariifolia prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat and help prevent wilting. If grown in shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, it's important to position this plant where it can enjoy abundant sunlight to ensure vigorous growth and a healthy bloom cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agastache scrophulariifolia is essential to maintain its shape and encourage robust growth. In early spring, before new growth begins, cut back any dead or damaged stems from the previous year. Once the plant has flowered, consider deadheading spent blooms to promote further flowering and to maintain a neat appearance. In late autumn, consider cutting back stems to near ground level as the plant enters dormancy. Regular pruning helps to enhance airflow and prevents fungal diseases by removing excess foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"purple giant hyssop","description":"Agastache scrophulariifolia, also known as the purple giant hyssop, is a perennial plant that grows throughout the US and Northern Ontario, CN. It is a beneficial plant to pollinators and is noted for its medicinal properties, as many plants in the mint family are. It tends to grow in disturbed or open areas where it does not have to interact with non-native competitive plants.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["purple giant hyssop"],"pest_susceptibility":["None recorded"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Agastache scrophulariifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16309,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dimorphocarpa wislizeni, also known as spectacle pod, is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers dry conditions. Watering should be infrequent but thorough, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In the growing season, water every couple of weeks or when the soil feels exceptionally dry. Reduce watering significantly in the winter months. This plant is adapted to arid environments, so overwatering can be more damaging than underwatering. Always ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dimorphocarpa wislizeni thrives in full sun exposure with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but growth and flowering may be less vigorous in shadier conditions. Ideally, position it in a location that receives morning sunlight and some afternoon shade to mimic its natural habitat. Adequate sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and blooming, so ensure that competing plants or structures do not overshadow it. Adaptability to sun exposure is one of its strengths, but optimal results are achieved with abundant light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dimorphocarpa wislizeni is generally minimal due to its natural growth habit. Pruning can be done in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and to encourage a more bushy appearance if desired. During the growing season, removing spent flowers can help redirect energy to new growth and flowering. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts to avoid damaging the plant. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the plant; light maintenance is usually sufficient for this species."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Touristplant","description":"Dimorphocarpa wislizeni, commonly known as spectacle pod, Wislizeni's spectaclepod, and touristplant, is a flowering plant in the mustard family native to western North America, where it occurs in the southwestern United States as far east as Oklahoma and Texas, and Baja California, Sonora, Chihuahua, and Coahuila in Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Touristplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dimorphocarpa wislizeni"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15897,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Jatropha podagrica is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. It is important to let the soil dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which spans spring through summer, water sparingly allowing the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. Reduce the frequency of watering in the winter as the plant enters its dormant phase. Over-watering can cause the stem to become soft or the roots to rot, so ensure that the pot has good drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jatropha podagrica thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sunlight. It should ideally be placed in a location where it can receive morning sun but avoid harsh afternoon sun which can scorch the leaves. A bright, east-facing window is often ideal. Insufficient light may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If placed indoors, ensure it gets bright, indirect light throughout the day. If grown outside, it can tolerate full sun but might need partial shade to protect from intense midday sunlight especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jatropha podagrica is a task that should be undertaken with care to maintain the plant's unique appearance and health. Prune the plant during early spring before the growing season begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and to maintain the plant's structure. Avoid heavy pruning, as Jatropha podagrica thrives with minimal intervention. Any pruning should be done using sterilized tools to prevent the spread of disease. Light pruning can also help in maintaining the desired shape and encouraging new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gout Stalk","description":"Jatropha podagrica is a species of plants known by several English common names, including Buddha belly plant, bottleplant shrub, gout plant, purging-nut, Guatemalan rhubarb, and goutystalk nettlespurge. It is native to the tropical Americas but it is propagated as an ornamental plant in many parts of the world.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Gout Stalk"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Jatropha podagrica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16408,"attracts":["birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Berlandier ash typically requires moderate watering. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out partially between watering sessions. Be careful not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. During dry spells or extreme heat, increase watering frequency to maintain soil moisture. Mulching can also help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature, which benefits this plant's root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fraxinus berlandieriana thrives in full sun to partial shade but prefers full sunlight for optimal growth. Ensure the plant receives at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, too much may lead to leggy growth and reduced foliage density. If your plant starts looking sparse or doesn’t thrive as expected, consider relocating it to a sunnier spot. In regions with harsh afternoon sun, providing some shade can prevent leaf scorch during peak heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berlandier ash should be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health. It’s also important to thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation and light penetration. Aim to shape the tree into a balanced form by trimming back overreaching branches. Avoid excessive pruning, which can stress the plant, and ensure all cuts are clean and at the branch collar to promote proper healing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican Ash","description":"Fraxinus berlandieriana (Mexican ash) is a tree native to eastern and northeastern Mexico and to the south-central United States. It has been reported from Tamaulipas, Veracruz, Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Mississippi.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Mexican Ash"],"pest_susceptibility":["Ash borer","Scale insects","Leaf curl aphid"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Fraxinus berlandieriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In the growing season, water deeply but infrequently, perhaps every 2-4 weeks depending on environmental conditions. Reduce watering in the dormant winter period to once every 1-2 months or only when soil is completely dry. Use well-draining soil that mimics its natural desert habitat. Overwatering is a common mistake, so always err on the side of less frequent watering with this cactus species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Escobaria alversonii thrives in full sun, similar to its natural desert habitat. Place the cactus in a location where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, a south or west-facing window is ideal. Gradually acclimate the plant to intense sunlight to prevent sunburn, especially if moving from a shaded or indoor environment. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent scorching during peak summer months. Adequate sunlight is key to promoting flowering and healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Escobaria alversonii is generally not necessary, as these cacti maintain a natural compact and tidy shape. However, you can remove any dead or damaged parts to prevent decay or pest issues. Use sterilized tools to make clean cuts, and prune during the spring or summer when the plant is actively growing. Take care not to damage the central stem or any offsets, as this can adversely affect the cactus's growth. Regular inspection for dead matter is useful for maintaining plant health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cushion Foxtail Cactus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Cushion Foxtail Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Heart rot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Escobaria alversonii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best to practice thinning cuts that remove branches at their origin rather than heading cuts, which can lead to excessive sprouting. Avoid pruning during the sap flow in early spring, as birches are prone to 'bleeding'. Regular pruning helps enhance air circulation within the tree and promotes a strong framework."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alaska Paper Birch","description":"Betula neoalaskana (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15501,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scutellaria elliptica, commonly known as Hairy Skullcap, requires moderate watering to thrive. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the active growing season, typically spring through fall, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Be cautious of overwatering, as it can lead to root rot, a common issue with this species if the soil remains too wet for prolonged periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scutellaria elliptica prefers partial to full sun conditions to thrive. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight each day. While it can tolerate full sun, particularly in cooler climates, providing some afternoon shade in hotter regions can help protect it from intense light and heat. If planted in a garden setting, consider its placement among taller plants or structures that might offer dappled light during the hottest parts of the day to prevent foliage scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scutellaria elliptica is not overly demanding, but occasional trimming can promote a healthier plant and encourage more robust growth. Pruning is best done in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems at their base. After the flowering period, you can also deadhead spent blooms to encourage additional flowering and maintain a tidy appearance. Lightly pruning the tips can help maintain the plant's shape and prevent it from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairy Skullcap","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Hairy Skullcap"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Scutellaria elliptica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17106,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trillium catesbaei, commonly known as Catesby's Trillium, requires consistently moist but well-draining soil. It thrives in environments that mimic its natural woodland habitat, where it enjoys humus-rich soil. The soil should not be allowed to dry out completely, especially during the growing season. Watering should be deep and regular, particularly in dry periods, to maintain the soil moisture. However, ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged soil as this can lead to root rot. During its dormant period in late summer to winter, reduce watering slightly but do not allow the soil to dry out entirely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Catesby's Trillium thrives best in partial shade to full shade, imitating its native deciduous forest environment. This plant benefits from dappled sunlight, especially in the morning and late afternoon, which can enhance its growth and flowering. However, too much direct midday sunlight can scorch the leaves, causing stress and inhibiting its blooming potential. The ideal placement is under the canopy of taller trees, where it can enjoy filtered sunlight. During its dormant period, there is flexibility in light exposure, but it's crucial to provide adequate shade during the active growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Trillium catesbaei is minimal, primarily focused on removing spent flowers and old foliage. After the blooming period, deadheading the flowers can be beneficial to prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production, potentially enhancing growth and flowering in the following seasons. Additionally, any yellowed or decaying leaves should be trimmed back to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Be careful when pruning, as the plant's growth is slow and its roots are sensitive. Avoid unnecessary pruning, as the plant relies on its foliage to gather energy for the next year's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bashful wakerobin","description":"Trillium catesbaei, also known as bashful wakerobin or rosy wake-robin, is a spring flowering perennial plant found in the southeastern United States. Like most trilliums, it prefers moist, humus-rich soil in shade. Its northern limit includes the Great Smoky Mountains and other parts of North Carolina and Tennessee. Most of its populations are in the Piedmont from North Carolina to Alabama, under deciduous trees such as American beech, various oak and hickory species, and tulip poplar....","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["bashful wakerobin"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Trillium catesbaei"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16118,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Callirhoe pedata, commonly known as the palmleaf poppy mallow, prefers moderate watering. During the growing season, water the plant when the soil feels dry to the touch, ideally about an inch below the surface. Be careful not to overwater, as this plant is susceptible to root rot if left in waterlogged soil. In regions with adequate rainfall, supplementary watering might not be necessary. During dormancy in the winter months, reduce watering frequency to prevent issues associated with excess moisture, allowing the soil to dry almost completely before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Callirhoe pedata thrives best in full sunlight but can also manage in partial shade conditions. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure optimal blooming and plant health. In regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can protect it from scorching. However, too much shade can result in spindly growth and fewer flowers. When planting, choose locations with a southern exposure that allows for ample sunlight, which will stimulate robust growth and allow the plant to showcase its vibrant, poppy-like blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Callirhoe pedata is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting healthier growth. Typically, this involves removing spent blooms throughout the growing season to encourage continuous flowering. Deadheading not only helps in redirecting the plant’s energy to producing more blooms but also prevents unwanted self-seeding. Additionally, in early spring, any dead or damaged stems from winter should be pruned back. This provides the plant with a fresh start and encourages vigorous new growth. A light trim may also be done after the flowering season to tidy the plant and maintain its desired size and shape."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Palmleaf winecup","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Palmleaf winecup"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Callirhoe pedata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15899,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cortinarius iodes, also known as the \"Viscid Violet Cortinarius,\" is a mushroom species rather than a plant, and does not require watering as traditional plants do. However, if you are cultivating this species or aiming to observe it in controlled environments, maintaining a moist substrate is essential. It thrives in damp, humid conditions typically found in forested areas. Keeping a humid ambient atmosphere will support healthy growth and replication of its natural habitat. The substrate should not be soggy; optimal fungal growth occurs when moisture levels are balanced and checked regularly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cortinarius iodes prefers low-light conditions, mimicking its natural woodland habitat where it often grows under tree canopies. Direct sunlight is not suitable for this species, as it can dry out the substrate and the fruiting bodies. If cultivating this mushroom indoors or in a terrarium setting, ensure it is placed in a shaded area away from direct light. The ambient light should be minimal, aiming to replicate the dappled light conditions of forest floor environments, ensuring the mushrooms maintain their moisture and growth potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Cortinarius iodes is a mushroom and not a plant, traditional pruning is not applicable. However, if you are cultivating or studying this species, it might be important to regularly check and remove any decaying or overly mature fruiting bodies to prevent mold and ensure air circulation around the fruiting area. This will help in maintaining healthy and vigorous mycelium growth in the substrate. During scientific collection, careful picking rather than pruning ensures accurate species identification and spore dispersal for continued fungal proliferation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Viscid Violet Cort","description":"Cortinarius iodes, commonly known as the spotted cort or the viscid violet cort, is a species of agaric fungus in the family Cortinariaceae. The fruit bodies have small, slimy, purple caps up to 6 cm (2.4 in) in diameter that develop yellowish spots and streaks in maturity. The gill color changes from violet to rusty or grayish brown as the mushroom matures. The species range includes the eastern North America, Central America, northern South America, and northern Asia,...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Viscid Violet Cort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cortinarius iodes"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This plant's preference for sunlit areas makes it ideal for sunny grasslands or wildflower gardens, where it can parasitize host roots nearby."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Rhinanthus serotinus doesn't require extensive pruning; however, managing this plant involves allowing it to self-seed if naturalizing is desired. You can deadhead the plant before it goes to seed to prevent excessive spreading and to encourage a tidier appearance. If you wish to collect seeds, wait until the seed pods are mature and rattling. It's important not to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Placing the pot on a pebble tray with water or using a humidifier can help maintain the right humidity level for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hymenophyllum sanguinolentum thrives under filtered light or dappled shade conditions similar to its natural rainforest environment. Direct sunlight can scorch its thin fronds, so it's best to place the fern in indirect light. If grown indoors, an east or north-facing window is ideal. If grown outdoors, ensure it is under a canopy or shaded area. Artificial lighting such as fluorescent bulbs can substitute if natural bright light is insufficient, but the exposure should still be indirect to avoid overheating or damage to the plant's delicate structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hymenophyllum sanguinolentum involves the careful removal of dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain an attractive appearance. Since these ferns are delicate, use sharp, clean scissors to snip away the unwanted fronds at the base, close to the rhizome. Regularly check for browned or diseased foliage, especially during seasonal changes, and remove them promptly. This not only helps in promoting new growth but also allows for better air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of pest infestations or fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Piripiri","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand","Australia","Fiji","Hawaii"],"other_name":["Piripiri"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Hymenophyllum sanguinolentum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
