{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16000,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave lophantha, also known as the thorn-crested agave, is a succulent that is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. Water it thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season in spring and summer, water around once every two weeks, reducing this to once a month during the dormant winter period. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the pot has adequate drainage. Observe the plant’s leaves; if they start to wrinkle or become wilted, it may need more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave lophantha thrives in bright sunlight and prefers full sun exposure for at least six hours a day. It is ideal to place the plant in a spot that receives direct sunlight, such as a south or west-facing window if indoors, or a sunny spot in the garden. Although it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to slower growth and a less healthy appearance. If grown indoors, rotating the plant occasionally will help it grow evenly and prevent it from leaning toward the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agave lophantha involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and improve its appearance. Use a clean, sharp knife or pruning shears to cut the leaves as close to the base as possible without damaging the main stem. Be sure to wear gloves and protective clothing, as the leaves can be sharp. Regularly prune away any offshoots if you want to maintain a single large plant instead of allowing it to spread. This should be done during the growing season to support quicker recovery and regeneration."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Thorn-crested Agave","description":"Agave univittata, the thorn-crested century plant or thorn-crested agave, is a plant species native to coastal areas of southern Texas and northeastern Mexico, at elevations less than 100 m (300 feet). It has been widely named Agave lophantha by botanists including Howard Scott Gentry, but the name A. univittata is older and therefore more in accord with nomenclatural rules of botany.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Thorn-crested Agave"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Offset propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agave lophantha"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16088,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Betula pumila, commonly known as bog birch, thrives in consistently moist to wet soils. To maintain optimal growth, ensure that the soil is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged; avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings. This plant is often found in wetland areas, so replicating these conditions at home is ideal. If you are growing it in a container, make sure there is adequate drainage, but keep a regular watering schedule, especially during dry seasons, to mimic its natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Betula pumila prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. If grown in a less sunny spot, ensure that other environmental conditions, such as soil moisture, are adequately maintained to compensate for reduced sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Betula pumila is generally minimal, focusing on maintaining its natural shape and health. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote healthy new growth. Additionally, you may thin out dense areas to improve air circulation and light penetration, which helps reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant; moderate maintenance is sufficient for this hardy species."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp birch","description":"Betula pumila (dwarf birch or bog birch) is a deciduous shrub native to North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17107,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trillium cernuum prefers consistently moist but not soggy soil. During the growing season, which is typically in spring and early summer, ensure the soil remains damp to the touch. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this can stress the plant and inhibit flowering. However, take caution to not overwater, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. During dormancy in late summer and fall, reduce watering considerably. It's beneficial to use mulch to help retain soil moisture and moderate temperature fluctuations."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trillium cernuum thrives in partial to full shade, as it is adapted to forest understory conditions. While it prefers filtered sunlight, it can tolerate early morning sun or dappled shade throughout the day. Avoid placing it in direct, intense sunlight as this can lead to leaf scorch and stress the plant. If you're planting it in a garden, choose a spot with naturally shaded conditions provided by trees or larger plants. Ensuring appropriate light conditions will encourage healthy growth and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Trillium cernuum is minimal and mostly involves removing any dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance. In hot, dry weather, you may need to water the fern more frequently. Always check the soil's moisture level before watering. Reducing the frequency during the plant's dormant winter period is also advisable, as a drier condition is preferred then."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dryopteris erythrosora thrives in partially shaded to shady conditions, mimicking its natural understory habitat. It does well in dappled sunlight or even full shade, although its fronds may exhibit a richer color with a bit of morning sun. However, it's important to keep it away from the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window to ensure it receives adequate indirect light. Adjust its location according to seasonal changes to maintain optimal light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dryopteris erythrosora is simple and primarily revolves around maintaining the plant's aesthetics and health. Remove any dead, damaged, or unsightly fronds as they appear to encourage new growth and reduce the risk of disease. The best time for major pruning is in early spring before new growth begins. Regularly trimming away old fronds not only tidies up the plant's appearance but also improves airflow, which helps mitigate fungal issues. After pruning, mulch the base to conserve moisture and insulate the roots."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"autumn fern","description":"Dryopteris erythrosora, the autumn fern, Japanese wood fern, or copper shield fern, is a species of fern in the family Dryopteridaceae, native to east Asia from China and Japan south to the Philippines, growing in light woodland shade on low mountains or hills. It is semi-evergreen, with bipinnate fronds 30–70 cm (12–28 in) tall by 15–35 cm (6–14 in) broad, with 8-20 pairs of pinnae. The fronds have a coppery tint when young, but mature to dark green.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Bronze, Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern Asia"],"other_name":["autumn fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Dryopteris erythrosora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16001,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave palmeri is highly drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. It thrives in well-drained soil and doesn't need frequent irrigation. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to let the soil completely dry out between waterings. Typically, watering once every two to three weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) is sufficient. In the winter, reduce watering to once a month or even less if kept indoors or in a cooler climate. Rainwater is ideal, but tap water at room temperature is also acceptable if left out to dechlorinate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave palmeri thrives in full sun conditions and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight ideally each day. It is well-suited for outdoor planting in areas with warm climates where it can soak up plenty of natural sunlight. If grown indoors or in areas with less intense sunlight, place the plant near a south-facing window or provide supplemental light through grow lights to mimic sunlight exposure. Ensure it gets ample light to prevent etiolation, where the plant stretches out and becomes leggy, seeking more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agave palmeri is minimal and mostly about removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. Use a clean, sharp knife or pruning shears to cut the leaves as close to the base as possible without damaging the central rosette. This helps prevent pests and diseases. Be cautious of the plant's sharp spines while pruning. Remember that agaves flower only once in their lifetime, so once the flowering stalk appears and completes its cycle, the main rosette dies, and pups should be encouraged to ensure new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Palmer's agave","description":"Agave palmeri (also known as Palmer's century plant) is an especially large member of the genus Agave, in the family Asparagaceae. It is native to southern Arizona, southwestern New Mexico, Sonora and Chihuahua. The plant is also frequently cultivated as an ornamental in other regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Palmer's agave"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agave palmeri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Still, maximizing sunlight is recommended for the best presentation and health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amphiachyris dracunculoides is not usually required for its health, but can be performed to control its shape or size. The soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. When planting, choose a location that receives morning sun with some afternoon protection if your climate has extremely hot summers. Planting in an area with good air circulation can also help prevent fungal diseases, which these plants can be prone to in humid conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox multiflora is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging vigorous growth and flowering. Deadhead spent flowers throughout the blooming season to promote continuous blooms. In late fall or early spring, cut back the plant by one-third to one-half of its height to remove dead or damaged stems and to tidy up the plant. This annual cutting promotes lush growth in the new season. Pinching the tips of new growth during the spring can also help to create a bushier plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"flowery phlox","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["flowery phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phlox multiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17506,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phedimus spurius, commonly known as two-row stonecrop, is a succulent that requires careful watering to thrive. It prefers a 'soak and dry' method, meaning you should water the plant thoroughly until water drains out from the bottom of the pot, then wait for the soil to dry out completely before watering again. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce the frequency of watering, as the plant goes into a period of dormancy and requires less moisture. Always ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phedimus spurius thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant foliage, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight per day. Too little sunlight can cause the plant to become leggy, while excessive direct sunlight, especially in very hot climates, can result in leaf scorch. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can enjoy plenty of natural light. In very sunny locations, providing some afternoon shade will help protect the plant from heat stress. Outdoors, a spot with morning sun and light afternoon shade works well."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phedimus spurius is generally minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. However, occasional pruning can promote a tidier appearance and encourage vigorous growth. Prune by pinching off any dead, damaged, or overly long stems. This can be done using sterilized scissors or pruning shears. Removing dead leaves and spent flowers will help the plant focus its energy on new growth. Ideally, pruning should be carried out during the growing season, typically in the spring and early summer, to encourage new, healthy growth and to maintain a compact form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Caucasian Stonecrop","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink, White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, Red"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Caucasus","Turkey","Iran"],"other_name":["Caucasian Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phedimus spurius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16512,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypericum ascyron, also known as Great St. John's Wort, prefers well-drained soil that is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, regular watering is essential to maintain healthy growth, especially in dry periods. However, be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. It's best to water deeply when the topsoil feels dry to the touch, allowing the water to reach the roots. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters dormancy. Always check that the soil drains well to avoid standing water around the plant's base."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade, though it performs best with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal flowering and growth. In hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to avoid leaf scorching. If planted in more shaded areas, it may produce fewer blooms and exhibit leggier growth. Ensure the site is open enough to receive adequate natural light throughout the day, and monitor the plant's response; if growth appears sparse, consider relocating it to a sunnier spot. Full sun will typically result in more vibrant flowers and a robust plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypericum ascyron is typically done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps to shape the plant and promote healthy flowering during the growing season. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems at the base to prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, cutting back old or leggy growth encourages new shoots, maintains a neat appearance, and improves airflow. You can cut back the stems by about a third to stimulate bushier growth. Light maintenance pruning may also be done in summer after flowering to remove spent blooms and prevent self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Great St. John's Wort","description":"Hypericum ascyron, the great St. Johnswort or giant St. John's wort is a wildflower in the genus Hypericum.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Asia"],"other_name":["Great St. John's Wort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hypericum ascyron"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16412,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fuchsia hybrida, commonly known as Fuchsia, requires regular watering to maintain consistently moist soil, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant thoroughly until water drains out from the bottom, and ensure the soil doesn’t dry out completely between waterings. In hot weather, these plants may need daily watering. However, cut back on watering during winter when growth slows. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil and avoid allowing it to stand in water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fuchsia hybrida thrives in conditions with bright, indirect sunlight. While it benefits from some direct morning sun, especially in cooler climates, it is essential to protect the plant from harsh, direct afternoon sunlight, which can scorch its delicate leaves. In warmer regions, consider planting Fuchsia in partial shade or under filtered light, such as beneath tree canopies or on east or north-facing areas. Adequate sunlight or light shade is crucial for encouraging optimal blooms and healthy plant development, so adjust exposure according to the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Fuchsia hybrida is essential to encourage bushy growth and abundant flowering. Pinch back the growing tips of young plants to promote branching. After the initial bloom, prune back about one-third of the plant's length to encourage a fresh burst of flowers. Also, remove any dead, weak, or crossing branches throughout the growing season. In late autumn, after flowering has stopped, reduce the plant back significantly, especially if growing as a perennial in colder climates, to prepare it for winter dormancy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hybrid fuchsia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Various, including pink, purple, red, and white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America","New Zealand"],"other_name":["hybrid fuchsia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Fuchsia hybrida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16910,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron lapponicum requires moderate watering, ensuring that the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. These plants do not tolerate drought or excessive dryness, particularly during their active growing season. It's important to water them deeply each time, allowing the water to reach the root zone, and then let the top few inches of soil dry out before watering again. Be cautious of overwatering, especially in environments with poor drainage, as this can lead to root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain a stable environment for the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron lapponicum thrives in partial shade conditions, where it receives filtered sunlight or dappled shade. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, prolonged exposure to strong, direct sunlight can scorch the leaves and stress the plant. Providing protection from harsh afternoon sun, particularly in hotter climates, is ideal. If grown in very shady areas, it may not bloom as prolifically, so balance is key. Planting it in an area where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade usually works best to sustain its growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron lapponicum should be done sparingly. Light pruning can be performed immediately after the flowering period to maintain the shape and remove any spent blooms or dead branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as this plant does not respond well to severe cuts. It's best to selectively prune branches to open up the plant, improving air circulation and allowing light to penetrate throughout. Avoid pruning late in the season as this can interfere with bud formation for the next bloom cycle. Proper pruning will help maintain a neat appearance and promote healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lapland Azalea","description":"Rhododendron lapponicum (Lapland rosebay, 高山杜鹃) is a rhododendron species found in subarctic regions around the world, where it grows at altitudes ranging from sea level to 1900 meters. It is a shrub that grows to 0.2–0.45 m in height, with leaves that are oblong-elliptic or ovate-elliptic to oblong-obovate, 0.4–1.5 by 0.2–0.5 cm in size. Flowers are reddish or purple.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Lapland Azalea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Bud blast"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron lapponicum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17407,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythrina americana, commonly known as the coral tree, prefers well-drained soil and doesn't require excessively frequent watering. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, from spring to early fall, water every 7-10 days depending on the climate; in hotter regions, more frequent watering might be necessary. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the soil from becoming completely dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythrina americana thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish. This exposure ensures vibrant blooms and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight might lead to sparse blooming and leggy growth. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. Ensure the plant is positioned in a spot that receives ample sunlight throughout the day for optimal performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Erythrina americana in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. This plant benefits from annual pruning to maintain shape, remove any dead or diseased branches, and encourage vigorous blooming. Focus on clearing out old, crossing branches and thinning the canopy to improve air circulation. Be cautious when pruning, as Erythrina species often have thorns or spines. Use sharp, clean tools to make clean cuts just above a bud or lateral branch to promote healthy new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American Coral Tree","description":"Erythrina America, (coral tree or colorines), is a flowering plant of the genus Erythrina which is native to Mexico. Colorín (plural colorines) is the name of a type of tree, Erythrina americana also called Tzompāmitl. The word colorín means color chillón—a “gaudy” or “loud” color (Williams 1959).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["American Coral Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Erythrina americana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16811,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlox nana, commonly known as Santa Fe Phlox, thrives best in well-draining soil and requires moderate watering. It's important to water these plants regularly during their growing season, ensuring the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. However, once established, Phlox nana becomes drought-tolerant and should only need supplemental watering during extended periods of dry weather. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, especially in humid conditions. Always water at the base to keep the foliage dry and minimize the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox nana thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, plant Phlox nana where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the foliage from scorching and help maintain soil moisture. While it can tolerate partial shade, the blooming may not be as prolific, and the plant might become leggier. Providing the right balance of sunlight ensures healthy, vigorous growth and a spectacular display of flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox nana is essential to encourage bushier growth and more prolific blooming. Begin by removing dead or damaged stems and spent flowers throughout the growing season to maintain a tidy appearance and redirect energy into new growth. In late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, cut back the previous year's stems to about six inches above the ground. This helps rejuvenate the plant and improve air circulation, reducing the risk of mildew and pest infestations. Regular deadheading can also prolong the blooming period."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Santa Fe phlox","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Santa Fe phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Phlox nana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it can tolerate partial shade, providing full sun will enhance its flowering and fruiting performance. In shaded conditions, the tree may grow slower and develop a less uniform canopy. Additionally, its tolerance to coastal conditions makes it ideal for coastal gardens where sunlight is abundant and salty air is present."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Calophyllum inophyllum is essential to maintain its shape and promote a healthier tree. Prune young trees to encourage a strong, central leader and eliminate any weak or crossing branches. Older trees benefit from the removal of dead, diseased, or damaged wood to reduce pest and disease problems. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring when the tree is dormant. Avoid heavy pruning, which can stress the tree, instead focus on light, corrective cuts. Regular pruning also maintains airflow through the canopy, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alexandrian Laurel","description":"Calophyllum inophyllum is a large evergreen, commonly called Alexandrian laurel balltree, beach calophyllum, beach touriga, beautyleaf, Borneo-mahogany, Indian doomba oiltree, Indian-laurel, laurelwood, red poon, satin touriga, and tacamahac-tree. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16612,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lyonia fruticosa, commonly known as the coastal plain staggerbush, prefers well-drained, slightly acidic soils and is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water young plants regularly until they are established, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. Mature plants should be watered sparingly, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it is essential to provide them with a well-drained location and to withhold water during rainy periods. Adjust the frequency of watering based on seasonal rainfall and temperature changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lyonia fruticosa thrives in full sunlight to partial shade conditions. It ideally prefers locations where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, it can also tolerate light shade, especially in hotter climates where some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. In areas with intense sun exposure, providing some filtered shade during the hottest parts of the day will help the plant maintain its vigor and lush appearance. The plant's location should be selected based on these sunlight needs to ensure healthy, robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lyonia fruticosa is generally unnecessary except to maintain its shape or remove dead or damaged branches. If pruning is desired, it should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts at the base of overgrown stems or just above a leaf node or lateral branch for shaping purposes. Regularly remove any suckers or unwanted growth to control its spread. Light pruning can encourage bushier growth and help maintain a tidy appearance in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"coastal plain staggerbush","description":"Lyonia fruticosa, the poor-grub or coastal plain staggerbush, is a plant species native to the US states of Florida, southern Georgia and the extreme southern part of South Carolina. It grows in pine woodlands and shrub bogs at elevations less than 100 meters (333 feet).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["coastal plain staggerbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lyonia fruticosa"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16208,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clematis vitalba, commonly known as Old Man's Beard or Traveller's Joy, requires consistent moisture, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. The soil should be kept evenly moist but well-drained to prevent root rot. It's important to water deeply to encourage deep root development and reduce surface evaporation. In hot weather, provide extra water, but allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. Reduce watering in fall to prepare the plant for its winter dormancy phase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis vitalba thrives in a location that provides full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of sunlight a day to promote abundant flowering. Morning sun with afternoon shade is perfect for hot, sunny climates, as it helps protect the plant from being scorched. Although it is tolerant of more shaded conditions, flowering may be reduced. For optimal health, aim to plant it in a site where the roots are shaded and cool, but the top of the plant can bask in the sun. A mulch or low-growing ground cover can help keep roots cool in hotter regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis vitalba is essential to manage its vigorous growth and encourage flowering. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. This plant blooms on new wood, so you can prune it back hard to a pair of strong buds about 12 inches from the ground. Be sure to remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the year to maintain plant health and shape. Regular pruning also helps to control its size and prevent it from becoming overly invasive in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Old man's beard","description":"Clematis vitalba (also known as old man's beard and traveller's joy) is a shrub of the Ranunculaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Old man's beard"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Clematis vitalba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Chalky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16082,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Berlandiera lyrata, commonly known as Chocolate Flower, prefers moderate watering. It's drought-tolerant once established, making it ideal for dry climates. During the growing season, water deeply once a week. Ensure soil is well-drained as it dislikes overly wet conditions. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Overwatering can lead to root rot. In very hot and dry areas, slightly increase the frequency, but always allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to mimic its natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chocolate Flower thrives in full sun, needing at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. It's well-suited to sunny spots where it can soak up maximum light. Insufficient sunlight can result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. While it tolerates some partial shade, especially in hot climates, full sun exposure ensures vibrant blossoms and a healthy, robust plant. When planting, choose a location with southern or western exposure to maximize sunlight, and avoid placing it in shaded or overly sheltered areas that might limit light access."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berlandiera lyrata is straightforward. Deadheading spent flowers will encourage more blooms and a tidier appearance. After the flowering season, typically in late autumn, cut back the plant by about one-third to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. If it becomes leggy, a stronger prune in early spring will rejuvenate the plant. However, avoid heavy pruning in late fall since it can affect the plant's hardiness over the winter months. Regularly remove any yellowing leaves or stems to keep the plant healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"lyre-leaf greeneyes","description":"Berlandiera lyrata, with the common names chocolate flower, chocolate daisy, or lyreleaf greeneyes, is a North American species of flowering plant in the sunflower family. The common name lyreleaf greeneyes is a reference to the shape of the leaf, which is curved like a lyre and the green disc which is left behind when the ray florets drop off which is thought to look like an eye.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["lyre-leaf greeneyes"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Berlandiera lyrata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. During the plant's active growth period in spring and summer, provide additional watering, while in winter, reduce the frequency. Monitor the plant for signs of dehydration such as wilting leaves, adjusting your watering habits accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus argutus grows best in full sun to partial shade, with a preference for full sunlight which aids in the production of sweet, plentiful berries. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure healthy growth and fruit production. While it can tolerate some shade, be mindful that reduced sunlight can lead to fewer and sourer berries. If planted in a shaded area, ensure it's still bright and no larger plants block too much light, as insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced yields."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus argutus is essential to maintain its shape, health, and fruit production. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased canes at their base. Thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation, which helps prevent disease. Once the plant has finished fruiting, cut back the floricanes (second-year canes) to ground level as they will not fruit again. Maintain the primocanes (first-year canes) for next year’s fruit. Regular pruning encourages vigorous new growth and maximizes berry yield."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sawtooth blackberry","description":"Rubus argutus is a North American species of prickly bramble in the rose family. It is a perennial native to the eastern and south-central United States from Florida to Texas, Missouri, Illinois, and Maine. Common names are sawtooth blackberry or tall blackberry because of its habit of growing up to 2 meters (80 inches) in height.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["sawtooth blackberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Cane borers","Fungal diseases","Mildew"],"propagation":["Root division","Stem cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rubus argutus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Additionally, consider the plant's location, as exposure to sunlight can increase its water requirements."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex grayi thrives best in conditions of partial to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive around 3-6 hours of morning or late afternoon sun, with some dappled shade during the hottest part of the day. Too much intense sunny exposure could stress the plant, causing leaf scorch. However, in areas with colder climates, more sunlight can be beneficial. If planted indoors or in a shaded garden, ensure that it receives indirect sunlight to support healthy growth. Adjust the plant’s position based on seasonal changes to provide optimal light exposure throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex grayi primarily involves removing dead or damaged foliage to maintain its health and appearance. This can be done at any time during the growing season. For a more thorough tidy-up, you may cut back the entire plant to a height of a few inches above the ground in early spring before new growth begins. This will encourage fresh growth and retain the plant’s neat appearance. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent disease, and remove cut foliage to keep the area tidy and reduce the chance of pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gray's sedge","description":"Carex grayi, commonly known as Gray's sedge, is a species of flowering plant in the Cyperaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Gray's sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex grayi"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to ensure that the plant does not dry out completely, especially during hot and dry periods. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. A good practice is to water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During rainy seasons, natural rainfall might suffice, but additional watering may be necessary in drier or more arid climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aethusa cynapium thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish. In regions with very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the plant from wilting under extreme heat. Too much shade can result in leggy growth and poor flowering. When planting, select a location where the plant will receive the appropriate amount of light. Adjust its position as needed to ensure optimal sunlight exposure for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aethusa cynapium is generally not necessary as this is an annual plant that doesn't require shaping or size control. However, you can deadhead the flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding if you do not want it to spread extensively. This involves cutting off spent flowers before they have the chance to develop seeds. This plant will die back naturally at the end of its growing season, at which point it should be removed from the area if you want to clean up the garden or prevent natural reseeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fool's parsley","description":"Aethusa cynapium (fool's parsley, fool's cicely, or poison parsley) is an annual (rarely biennial) herb in the plant family Apiaceae, native to Europe, western Asia, and northwest Africa. It is the only member of the genus Aethusa. It is related to Hemlock and Water-dropwort, and like them it is poisonous, though less so than hemlock. It has been introduced into many other parts of the world and is a common weed in cultivated ground.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Fool's parsley"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aethusa cynapium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

Regularly inspect the moss and remove debris, dead or discolored leaves gently by hand or with tweezers. Pruning helps keep the moss carpet tidy and encourages new growth. Avoid cutting the healthy parts aggressively, as mosses grow slower compared to other plants. If moss carpets become too dense or compact, gently tease apart sections to improve air circulation, which helps prevent mold and disease build-up in dense clusters."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Waxyleaf Moss","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Waxyleaf Moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Dicranum polysetum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16405,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus pumila, commonly known as the Creeping Fig, prefers to be kept in consistently moist soil. However, it's important to ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly and then allow the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. During the warmer months, you might need to water more frequently, while in the winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows. It's essential to maintain a balance, as both overwatering and underwatering can cause the plant to suffer."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus pumila thrives in bright, indirect light, but it can tolerate low-light conditions, making it a versatile houseplant. Avoid exposing the plant to direct sunlight, especially intense afternoon rays, as this can scorch the leaves. If placed in an area with lower light, the plant may grow more slowly and produce less dense foliage. You can place it near an east-facing window where it can receive gentle morning sun or filter intense light with a sheer curtain. If you notice the plant becoming leggy, it might indicate it needs more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus pumila is essential to control its rapid growth and to maintain a desired shape. It can be pruned at any time of the year, but it's often best to trim it in the spring when new growth starts. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15204,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vernonia baldwinii, commonly known as Baldwin's ironweed, prefers consistent moisture but is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant regularly during its first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system, and reduce the frequency afterward. During prolonged dry periods, additional watering may help maintain its vibrant appearance, although it can survive with minimal watering. Be careful not to overwater, as it may lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is well-drained, as standing water is detrimental. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and moderate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Baldwin's ironweed thrives in full sun to partial shade, though it performs best with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, reduced sunlight can lead to fewer blooms and a leggy growth habit. To support sturdy stems and vibrant blooms, plant Vernonia baldwinii in a location with ample sunlight exposure. If planted in a shadier spot, it may require support to prevent flopping. For optimal blooming and growth, choose a site that receives generous sunshine throughout the day. Exposure to morning and afternoon sun is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernonia baldwinii is mostly about maintaining its shape and encouraging a bushier growth habit. Cut back the plant in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems from the previous season’s growth. Doing so will stimulate new growth. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can prolong the blooming period. In late fall or early spring, it’s a good idea to cut the plant back to about 6 inches above the ground to tidy up its appearance and promote healthy growth. This perennial generally does well without extensive pruning beyond these basic practices."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Ironweed","description":"Vernonia baldwinii, the western ironweed or Baldwin's ironweed, is a perennial herb native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Western Ironweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vernonia baldwinii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure consistent dappled or indirect sunlight exposure for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Carex deweyana is minimal and generally involves cleaning away dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth. It is a spreading, matted perennial with opposite leaves, often mottled because of a virus that attacks the foliage. Flowers are white, cross-shaped with 4 petals. This can be done throughout the growing season to encourage further flowering and maintain a neat appearance. Avoid heavy pruning during late summer or fall to ensure the plant's energy is focused on overwintering. Regular pruning also helps improve air circulation, reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spotted horse mint","description":"Monarda punctata is a herbaceous plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae, that is native to eastern Canada, the eastern United States and northeastern Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16406,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Firmiana simplex, commonly known as the Chinese parasol tree, prefers moderate watering. Ensure the soil is well-drained, as this tree does not do well in waterlogged conditions. During its active growing season in spring and summer, water it regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Reduce watering frequency in the dormant winter months. Always check the top layer of soil; when it starts to dry out slightly, it's time to water again, but avoid allowing it to completely dry out or remain overly wet."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Firmiana simplex thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure optimal growth and development. While it can tolerate light shade, too much shading might result in reduced flowering and slower growth. In regions with intense, scorching sun, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Position this tree where it can enjoy all the benefits of sun exposure for healthier foliage and structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Firmiana simplex should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree’s health. You may also prune to shape the tree or control its size, focusing on maintaining an open canopy for sufficient air circulation. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, ensuring any larger cuts are made just outside the branch collar to promote proper healing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese parasol tree","description":"Firmiana simplex, commonly known as the Chinese parasol tree, Chinese parasoltree, or wutong (Chinese: 梧桐; pinyin: wútóng), is an ornamental plant of tree size that has recently been assigned to the family Malvaceae and was formerly the Cacao Family (Chocolate Family) Sterculiaceae in the order Malvales, and is native to Asia. It grows up to 16 m (52 ft) tall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China","Taiwan"],"other_name":["Chinese parasol tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Firmiana simplex"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. In drier regions or during periods of drought, increase the frequency of watering. The plant is somewhat tolerant of short dry spells once established but performs best with regular moisture. To conserve moisture and maintain a stable environment for the roots, adding a layer of mulch around the base is beneficial. Reduce watering in late fall and winter as the plant goes dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Callicarpa dichotoma thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal berry production and vibrant foliage, planting in an area that receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day is recommended. In hotter climates, afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. However, in too much shade, the plant may produce fewer berries and have a leggier appearance. A balance between sun and shade will foster healthy growth and abundant berry displays, making it important to consider the plant's sun exposure when selecting its location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Callicarpa dichotoma is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This plant blooms on new wood, so pruning at this time encourages the development of flowering stems. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation and aesthetics. Cut back the plant to about one-third of its size to promote a fuller shape and enhance berry production in the coming season. Light shaping can be done after flowering, but extensive pruning should be saved for the dormant season to prevent loss of berries."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple Beautyberry","description":"Callicarpa dichotoma (common names, Purple Beautyberry or Early Amethyst) is species of beautyberry. They are cultivated as garden trees. The flowers are pink to white. The berries which are small drupes are purple. The fruits grow closely together in large clusters. The fruit provides food for wild life. The berries are bitter and are unfit for culinary use. This species can be found in China, Vietnam, Korea and Japan.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","China","Korea"],"other_name":["Purple Beautyberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Callicarpa dichotoma"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning during late fall or winter, as this can stress the plant during colder months."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common dittany","description":"Cunila origanoides — common names stone mint, frost mint, dittany, and American dittany — is a perennial late-summer-flowering subshrub with small purple flowers, which is native to the Eastern United States. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15595,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Selaginella selaginoides, commonly known as spike moss, prefers consistently moist soil but not waterlogged conditions. It's important to water this plant regularly, ensuring the soil never dries out completely. In general, watering once or twice a week should suffice, but adjust based on the plant's environment—more frequent watering may be required in warmer conditions or if the air is particularly dry. Always use room temperature water to avoid shocking the plant. Reduce watering slightly during the winter months as growth slows down, but never allow the substrate to dry out entirely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Selaginella selaginoides thrives in environments with medium to bright indirect light. Direct sunlight should be avoided, as it can scorch and damage the delicate foliage. However, the plant should not be kept in low light for extended periods, as this can lead to leggy growth and pale leaves. An ideal location would be near a window that receives filtered light or in a well-lit room away from the direct sun. If natural light is inadequate, consider using fluorescent lights to supplement the plant’s lighting needs, particularly during shorter winter days."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Selaginella selaginoides is generally minimal, as this plant does not require much shaping. Remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain its appearance and enhance air circulation, which helps prevent disease. Trim away any yellowing or dying leaves as soon as they appear, using clean scissors or pruning shears to make a neat cut. This process can be done throughout the year. Pruning encourages new growth and can help retain a compact form if desired. Although not mandatory, periodic pruning supports healthier growth and can potentially encourage denser foliage development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"northern spikemoss","description":"Selaginella selaginoides is a non-flowering plant of the spikemoss genus Selaginella with a wide distribution around the Northern Hemisphere. It resembles a moss in appearance but is a vascular plant belonging to the division Lycopodiophyta. The key to watering this plant is to let the soil dry out completely before watering again. Over-watering can lead to root rot, which is detrimental to its health. During hot, dry periods, you can water more frequently, but always check the soil moisture first. It is better to water deeply and less frequently to encourage deep root growth, compared to frequent shallow watering. Provide good drainage to ensure the soil does not remain waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gaillardia pinnatifida thrives best in full sun conditions, which means it requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It is tolerant of high heat and dry conditions, making it well-suited for sunny, arid regions. Full sunlight helps the plant produce vibrant flowers and supports robust growth. Insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and a leggy appearance. If planting in a garden, choose a location where it will receive unobstructed sunlight. If growing in containers, make sure to position them in a sunny spot to meet the light needs of this sun-loving plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gaillardia pinnatifida is not very demanding, but it can help maintain a tidy appearance and promote more blooms. The best time to prune is in early spring before the plant begins its new growth. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can be done throughout the flowering season to encourage continuous blooming. In late fall, you can cut back the plant to approximately 6 inches above the ground to help it overwinter and encourage healthier growth in the following season. Regular pruning also helps prevent legginess and keeps the plant bushy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red dome blanketflower","description":"Gaillardia pinnatifida (Hopi blanketflower or red dome blanketflower) is a perennial plant in the sunflower family (Asteraceae) found in northern Mexico (Chihuahua, Coahuila, Durango, Sonora) and in the south-central and southwestern United States (from southwestern Kansas south to central Texas and west as far as southern Nevada).:78","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["red dome blanketflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Gaillardia pinnatifida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the first frost, trim old foliage back to the rhizome, preparing the plant for dormancy in colder climates."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dotleaf Waterlily","description":"Nymphaea ampla, the dotleaf waterlily, is a species of flowering plant in the family Nymphaeaceae. It is essential to keep the soil evenly damp, especially during hot, dry periods. However, ensure that the roots do not sit in standing water to prevent root rot. Mulching around the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. During times of regular rainfall, less additional watering may be necessary. Test the soil with your finger - if the top inch is dry, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox carolina thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal blooming. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and prolong blooming. When planting in partial shade, ensure that the plant receives enough light for vibrant flower production. This plant is adaptable to different light conditions but will flower best with sufficient sunlight exposure. Adjust positioning if blooms decline or the plant appears leggy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox carolina involves removing dead or faded flowers to encourage continuous blooming throughout its planting season. This is known as deadheading and should be done regularly. It is also beneficial to cut back the plant in the late fall after blooming has finished or in early spring before new growth begins. This promotes healthy, vigorous growth and helps maintain a neat appearance. When pruning, always use sterilized tools to prevent disease transmission, and cut stems back to the base to encourage bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"thickleaf phlox","description":"Phlox carolina, the thickleaf phlox, is a species of flowering plant in the family Polemoniaceae. It is an herbaceous perennial growing to 1.2 m (4 ft) tall by 45 cm (18 in) wide, with leaves to 13 cm (5 in) long, and purple or pink flowers in summer. The specific epithet carolina refers to its native habitat in the eastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["thickleaf phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Phlox carolina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. The plant can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in fewer flowers and a leggier appearance. It is adaptable to a variety of conditions, but the more sunlight it receives, the more robust and floriferous it will be. Ensuring adequate sunlight helps maintain its compact form and enhances the aromatic qualities of its leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agastache foeniculum is mainly about promoting bushiness and prolonging blooming. Deadhead the flowers regularly during the blooming season to encourage more flower production. Cut back the entire plant by about one-third in mid-summer if it becomes leggy or starts to decline in flowering, which will spur fresh growth and potentially another round of blooms. In hotter regions, providing light afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from becoming stressed or wilted. Insufficient sunlight may lead to poor flowering and leggy growth. Ensure that it is planted in a location that maximizes sunlight exposure while minimizing excessive heat during peak midday sun. Adjustments might be necessary if the plant shows signs of sunburn or too much shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox cuspidata helps promote healthy growth and a tidy appearance. In the early spring, before new growth begins, remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage vigorous growth. During the blooming season, regularly deadhead spent flowers to prolong the blooming period and redirect energy into producing more flowers rather than seeds. After flowering finishes, cutting back the stems by about one-third can promote bushier growth and prevent the plant from looking too leggy. This maintenance helps ensure the plant remains healthy and attractive throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pointed phlox","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["pointed phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phlox cuspidata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Watering should be infrequent but thorough, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In the growing season, water every couple of weeks or when the soil feels exceptionally dry. Reduce watering significantly in the winter months. This plant is adapted to arid environments, so overwatering can be more damaging than underwatering. Always ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dimorphocarpa wislizeni thrives in full sun exposure with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but growth and flowering may be less vigorous in shadier conditions. Ideally, position it in a location that receives morning sunlight and some afternoon shade to mimic its natural habitat. Adequate sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and blooming, so ensure that competing plants or structures do not overshadow it. Adaptability to sun exposure is one of its strengths, but optimal results are achieved with abundant light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dimorphocarpa wislizeni is generally minimal due to its natural growth habit. Pruning can be done in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and to encourage a more bushy appearance if desired. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the plant; light maintenance is usually sufficient for this species."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Touristplant","description":"Dimorphocarpa wislizeni, commonly known as spectacle pod, Wislizeni's spectaclepod, and touristplant, is a flowering plant in the mustard family native to western North America, where it occurs in the southwestern United States as far east as Oklahoma and Texas, and Baja California, Sonora, Chihuahua, and Coahuila in Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Touristplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dimorphocarpa wislizeni"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Reduce the frequency of watering in the winter as the plant enters its dormant phase. Over-watering can cause the stem to become soft or the roots to rot, so ensure that the pot has good drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jatropha podagrica thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sunlight. It should ideally be placed in a location where it can receive morning sun but avoid harsh afternoon sun which can scorch the leaves. A bright, east-facing window is often ideal. Insufficient light may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If placed indoors, ensure it gets bright, indirect light throughout the day. If grown outside, it can tolerate full sun but might need partial shade to protect from intense midday sunlight especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jatropha podagrica is a task that should be undertaken with care to maintain the plant's unique appearance and health. Prune the plant during early spring before the growing season begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and to maintain the plant's structure. Light pruning can also help in maintaining the desired shape and encouraging new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gout Stalk","description":"Jatropha podagrica is a species of plants known by several English common names, including Buddha belly plant, bottleplant shrub, gout plant, purging-nut, Guatemalan rhubarb, and goutystalk nettlespurge. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out partially between watering sessions. Be careful not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. During dry spells or extreme heat, increase watering frequency to maintain soil moisture. Mulching can also help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature, which benefits this plant's root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fraxinus berlandieriana thrives in full sun to partial shade but prefers full sunlight for optimal growth. Ensure the plant receives at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, too much may lead to leggy growth and reduced foliage density. If your plant starts looking sparse or doesn’t thrive as expected, consider relocating it to a sunnier spot. In regions with harsh afternoon sun, providing some shade can prevent leaf scorch during peak heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berlandier ash should be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health. It’s also important to thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation and light penetration. Aim to shape the tree into a balanced form by trimming back overreaching branches. Avoid excessive pruning, which can stress the plant, and ensure all cuts are clean and at the branch collar to promote proper healing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican Ash","description":"Fraxinus berlandieriana (Mexican ash) is a tree native to eastern and northeastern Mexico and to the south-central United States. However, you can remove any dead or damaged parts to prevent decay or pest issues. Use sterilized tools to make clean cuts, and prune during the spring or summer when the plant is actively growing. Take care not to damage the central stem or any offsets, as this can adversely affect the cactus's growth. Regular pruning also helps to control the tree's size and prevent it from becoming too dense or unmanageable. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can stress the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shamel Ash","description":"Fraxinus uhdei, commonly known as tropical ash or Shamel ash, is a species of tree native to Mexico and Central America. It's essential to water the young birch deeply and regularly, especially during dry spells, to help establish a robust root system. Once established, Alaska birch is relatively drought tolerant but prefers moist, well-drained soils. Be cautious not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alaska birch thrives best in full sun, where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth occurs with more exposure to sunlight. Adequate sunlight ensures that the tree maintains a healthy growth pattern and vibrant foliage. When planting Betula neoalaskana, choose a location in your garden that gets morning sunshine and some protection from the intense afternoon sun, especially in warmer climates, to help it thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Betula neoalaskana should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Prune away dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. It's best to practice thinning cuts that remove branches at their origin rather than heading cuts, which can lead to excessive sprouting. Avoid pruning during the sap flow in early spring, as birches are prone to 'bleeding'. Regular pruning helps enhance air circulation within the tree and promotes a strong framework."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alaska Paper Birch","description":"Betula neoalaskana (syn. B. resinifera) or Alaska birch, also known as Alaska paper birch or resin birch, is a species of birch native to Alaska and northern Canada. During prolonged dry spells, you may need to water more, ensuring that you provide a deep watering to encourage root growth. Avoid overwatering, as it can cause more harm than good to this resilient plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hymenopappus artemisiifolius thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. In extremely hot climates, providing light afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the harshest rays of the sun, but ensure it still receives predominant sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hymenopappus artemisiifolius is generally minimal. It is mainly done to maintain shape and promote a bushier growth habit. You can remove spent flowers to encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from focusing energy on seed production. Light pruning is best performed in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems and thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as this plant does not require it and may take longer to recover from excessive cutting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Old Plainsman","description":"Hymenopappus artemisiifolius, the oldplainsman, is a North American species of flowering plant in the daisy family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17106,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trillium catesbaei, commonly known as Catesby's Trillium, requires consistently moist but well-draining soil. It thrives in environments that mimic its natural woodland habitat, where it enjoys humus-rich soil. The soil should not be allowed to dry out completely, especially during the growing season. Watering should be deep and regular, particularly in dry periods, to maintain the soil moisture. However, ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged soil as this can lead to root rot. During its dormant period in late summer to winter, reduce watering slightly but do not allow the soil to dry out entirely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Catesby's Trillium thrives best in partial shade to full shade, imitating its native deciduous forest environment. This plant benefits from dappled sunlight, especially in the morning and late afternoon, which can enhance its growth and flowering. However, too much direct midday sunlight can scorch the leaves, causing stress and inhibiting its blooming potential. The ideal placement is under the canopy of taller trees, where it can enjoy filtered sunlight. During its dormant period, there is flexibility in light exposure, but it's crucial to provide adequate shade during the active growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Trillium catesbaei is minimal, primarily focused on removing spent flowers and old foliage. After the blooming period, deadheading the flowers can be beneficial to prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production, potentially enhancing growth and flowering in the following seasons. Additionally, any yellowed or decaying leaves should be trimmed back to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Be careful when pruning, as the plant's growth is slow and its roots are sensitive. Avoid unnecessary pruning, as the plant relies on its foliage to gather energy for the next year's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bashful wakerobin","description":"Trillium catesbaei, also known as bashful wakerobin or rosy wake-robin, is a spring flowering perennial plant found in the southeastern United States. Like most trilliums, it prefers moist, humus-rich soil in shade. Its northern limit includes the Great Smoky Mountains and other parts of North Carolina and Tennessee. Most of its populations are in the Piedmont from North Carolina to Alabama, under deciduous trees such as American beech, various oak and hickory species, and tulip poplar....","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["bashful wakerobin"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Trillium catesbaei"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16908,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhinanthus serotinus, commonly known as yellow rattle, is a semi-parasitic plant that typically thrives in well-drained, moderately dry to moist soils. It does not require frequent watering if planted in its typical meadow or grassland habitat, as it relies partly on the host plants. Regular natural rainfall is usually sufficient.
