{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17206,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Suillus granulatus, a mycorrhizal fungus associated with coniferous trees, generally does not require direct watering when growing naturally, as it typically receives moisture from its forest environment. If cultivating this mushroom in a controlled environment, maintain moisture in the substrate through regular misting. Ensure the substrate remains damp but not overly wet to prevent rot and mold. Consistent humidity levels between 85-90% are ideal for optimal growth. Avoid standing water as this may harm the mycelium. Inoculated areas should be misted lightly and frequently to maintain a suitable growing environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Suillus granulatus does not require direct sunlight for growth, as it is typically found in shaded coniferous forests under the canopy of trees. For cultivation or if searching for them in the wild, conditions that simulate a forest floor with dappled light or full shade should be provided. Avoid exposing the mycelium or fruiting bodies to direct sunlight as this could dry them out and inhibit growth. Maintaining an environment with stable temperatures and humidity levels, mimicking their natural habitat, is more critical than light exposure for successful growth and fruiting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Suillus granulatus, as it is a mushroom species rather than a vascular plant. However, when harvesting the mushrooms, it’s advisable to cut them at the base with a sharp knife or twist gently to remove them without disturbing the surrounding mycelium. This practice can aid in continued production and health of the fungus. Regularly check for any decaying mushrooms and remove them to prevent contamination and to ensure healthy growth conditions for young, developing fruiting bodies."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dotted-stalked Suillus","description":"Suillus granulatus is a pored mushroom of the genus Suillus in the family Suillaceae. It is similar to the related S. luteus, but can be distinguished by its ringless stalk. Like S. luteus, it is an edible mushroom that often grows in a symbiosis (mycorrhiza) with pine. It has been commonly known as the weeping bolete, or the granulated bolete.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Dotted-stalked Suillus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Suillus granulatus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16119,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Callisia fragrans, commonly known as the basket plant or inch plant, prefers a well-draining soil mix and does not need to be kept constantly moist. Water the plant when the top 1-2 inches of soil feel dry to the touch. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Allow water to drain thoroughly and empty the saucer under the pot if necessary. In winter, the plant's growth slows, and it requires less frequent watering. Ensure the pot has drainage holes to prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Callisia fragrans thrives in bright, indirect light, but it can also tolerate low-light conditions, making it versatile in various indoor settings. However, the plant will perform best and show more vibrant growth in bright, filtered sunlight. Avoid direct sunlight as it may scorch the leaves, especially during the peak of summer. If placed in low-light areas, growth may slow, and the foliage could become less vibrant. If possible, place your plant near an east or west-facing window for optimal light exposure, and consider rotating the plant periodically for even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is beneficial for encouraging bushier growth in Callisia fragrans. Regularly trim the plant to remove any leggy or overgrown stems. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut just above a leaf node to encourage new branching. Pruning can also help maintain the plant’s shape and remove any damaged or dead leaves or stems. Pruning is best done during the growing season in spring or early summer. Cuttings can also be propagated to grow new plants if desired, making pruning both a maintenance task and a way to expand your collection."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"False Bromeliad Plant","description":"Callisia fragrans, commonly known as the basket plant, chain plant or inch plant, is a species of the Callisia genus, in the Commelinaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["False Bromeliad Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Callisia fragrans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15600,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dryopteris erythrosora, commonly known as the autumn fern, prefers consistently moist soil but does not like standing water. It is important to water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In hot, dry weather, you may need to water the fern more frequently. Always check the soil's moisture level before watering. Reducing the frequency during the plant's dormant winter period is also advisable, as a drier condition is preferred then."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dryopteris erythrosora thrives in partially shaded to shady conditions, mimicking its natural understory habitat. It does well in dappled sunlight or even full shade, although its fronds may exhibit a richer color with a bit of morning sun. However, it's important to keep it away from the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window to ensure it receives adequate indirect light. Adjust its location according to seasonal changes to maintain optimal light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dryopteris erythrosora is simple and primarily revolves around maintaining the plant's aesthetics and health. Remove any dead, damaged, or unsightly fronds as they appear to encourage new growth and reduce the risk of disease. The best time for major pruning is in early spring before new growth begins. Regularly trimming away old fronds not only tidies up the plant's appearance but also improves airflow, which helps mitigate fungal issues. After pruning, mulch the base to conserve moisture and insulate the roots."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"autumn fern","description":"Dryopteris erythrosora, the autumn fern, Japanese wood fern, or copper shield fern, is a species of fern in the family Dryopteridaceae, native to east Asia from China and Japan south to the Philippines, growing in light woodland shade on low mountains or hills. It is semi-evergreen, with bipinnate fronds 30–70 cm (12–28 in) tall by 15–35 cm (6–14 in) broad, with 8-20 pairs of pinnae. The fronds have a coppery tint when young, but mature to dark green.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Bronze, Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern Asia"],"other_name":["autumn fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Dryopteris erythrosora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16001,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave palmeri is highly drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. It thrives in well-drained soil and doesn't need frequent irrigation. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to let the soil completely dry out between waterings. Typically, watering once every two to three weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) is sufficient. In the winter, reduce watering to once a month or even less if kept indoors or in a cooler climate. Rainwater is ideal, but tap water at room temperature is also acceptable if left out to dechlorinate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave palmeri thrives in full sun conditions and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight ideally each day. It is well-suited for outdoor planting in areas with warm climates where it can soak up plenty of natural sunlight. If grown indoors or in areas with less intense sunlight, place the plant near a south-facing window or provide supplemental light through grow lights to mimic sunlight exposure. Ensure it gets ample light to prevent etiolation, where the plant stretches out and becomes leggy, seeking more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agave palmeri is minimal and mostly about removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. Use a clean, sharp knife or pruning shears to cut the leaves as close to the base as possible without damaging the central rosette. This helps prevent pests and diseases. Be cautious of the plant's sharp spines while pruning. Remember that agaves flower only once in their lifetime, so once the flowering stalk appears and completes its cycle, the main rosette dies, and pups should be encouraged to ensure new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Palmer's agave","description":"Agave palmeri (also known as Palmer's century plant) is an especially large member of the genus Agave, in the family Asparagaceae. It is native to southern Arizona, southwestern New Mexico, Sonora and Chihuahua. The plant is also frequently cultivated as an ornamental in other regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Palmer's agave"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agave palmeri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17406,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pseudobombax ellipticum, also known as the shaving brush tree or pink bombax, prefers moderate watering. During its growing season, which is typically in the spring and summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings, especially in cooler months, to maintain optimal soil moisture and prevent fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pseudobombax ellipticum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily, especially during its active growing season. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure promotes the best flowering and overall growth. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. During its growth period, occasional deep watering can help maintain vigor, especially in extreme heat, but letting the soil dry out between waterings is recommended. Still, maximizing sunlight is recommended for the best presentation and health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amphiachyris dracunculoides is not usually required for its health, but can be performed to control its shape or size. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can encourage prolonged blooming and prevent unwanted self-seeding if the spread of the plant is undesirable. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins to ensure optimal shape and form for the growing season. Additionally, removing any dead or damaged stems can help maintain overall plant health. Wear gloves while pruning to protect your hands from any potentially irritating sap."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prairie broomweed","description":"Amphiachyris dracunculoides (broomweed) is a North American species of flowering plants in the daisy family. The soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During hot and dry periods, increase the frequency of watering to prevent the plant from drying out. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters a dormant phase, but do not let the soil become completely dry. Drip irrigation can be beneficial for providing steady moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox multiflora thrives in full sun to partial shade, although full sun is preferred for optimal flowering. Aim for at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some light shade, too much shade will result in fewer flowers and weaker plant growth. When planting, choose a location that receives morning sun with some afternoon protection if your climate has extremely hot summers. Planting in an area with good air circulation can also help prevent fungal diseases, which these plants can be prone to in humid conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox multiflora is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging vigorous growth and flowering. Deadhead spent flowers throughout the blooming season to promote continuous blooms. In late fall or early spring, cut back the plant by one-third to one-half of its height to remove dead or damaged stems and to tidy up the plant. This annual cutting promotes lush growth in the new season. Pinching the tips of new growth during the spring can also help to create a bushier plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"flowery phlox","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["flowery phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phlox multiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers a 'soak and dry' method, meaning you should water the plant thoroughly until water drains out from the bottom of the pot, then wait for the soil to dry out completely before watering again. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce the frequency of watering, as the plant goes into a period of dormancy and requires less moisture. Always ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phedimus spurius thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant foliage, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight per day. Too little sunlight can cause the plant to become leggy, while excessive direct sunlight, especially in very hot climates, can result in leaf scorch. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can enjoy plenty of natural light. In very sunny locations, providing some afternoon shade will help protect the plant from heat stress. Outdoors, a spot with morning sun and light afternoon shade works well."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phedimus spurius is generally minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. However, occasional pruning can promote a tidier appearance and encourage vigorous growth. Prune by pinching off any dead, damaged, or overly long stems. This can be done using sterilized scissors or pruning shears. Removing dead leaves and spent flowers will help the plant focus its energy on new growth. Ideally, pruning should be carried out during the growing season, typically in the spring and early summer, to encourage new, healthy growth and to maintain a compact form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Caucasian Stonecrop","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink, White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, Red"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Caucasus","Turkey","Iran"],"other_name":["Caucasian Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phedimus spurius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, regular watering is essential to maintain healthy growth, especially in dry periods. However, be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. It's best to water deeply when the topsoil feels dry to the touch, allowing the water to reach the roots. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters dormancy. Always check that the soil drains well to avoid standing water around the plant's base."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade, though it performs best with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal flowering and growth. In hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to avoid leaf scorching. If planted in more shaded areas, it may produce fewer blooms and exhibit leggier growth. Ensure the site is open enough to receive adequate natural light throughout the day, and monitor the plant's response; if growth appears sparse, consider relocating it to a sunnier spot. Full sun will typically result in more vibrant flowers and a robust plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypericum ascyron is typically done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps to shape the plant and promote healthy flowering during the growing season. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems at the base to prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, cutting back old or leggy growth encourages new shoots, maintains a neat appearance, and improves airflow. You can cut back the stems by about a third to stimulate bushier growth. Light maintenance pruning may also be done in summer after flowering to remove spent blooms and prevent self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Great St. John's Wort","description":"Hypericum ascyron, the great St. Johnswort or giant St. John's wort is a wildflower in the genus Hypericum.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Asia"],"other_name":["Great St. John's Wort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hypericum ascyron"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16412,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fuchsia hybrida, commonly known as Fuchsia, requires regular watering to maintain consistently moist soil, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant thoroughly until water drains out from the bottom, and ensure the soil doesn’t dry out completely between waterings. In hot weather, these plants may need daily watering. However, cut back on watering during winter when growth slows. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil and avoid allowing it to stand in water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fuchsia hybrida thrives in conditions with bright, indirect sunlight. While it benefits from some direct morning sun, especially in cooler climates, it is essential to protect the plant from harsh, direct afternoon sunlight, which can scorch its delicate leaves. In warmer regions, consider planting Fuchsia in partial shade or under filtered light, such as beneath tree canopies or on east or north-facing areas. Adequate sunlight or light shade is crucial for encouraging optimal blooms and healthy plant development, so adjust exposure according to the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Fuchsia hybrida is essential to encourage bushy growth and abundant flowering. Pinch back the growing tips of young plants to promote branching. After the initial bloom, prune back about one-third of the plant's length to encourage a fresh burst of flowers. Also, remove any dead, weak, or crossing branches throughout the growing season. In late autumn, after flowering has stopped, reduce the plant back significantly, especially if growing as a perennial in colder climates, to prepare it for winter dormancy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hybrid fuchsia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Various, including pink, purple, red, and white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America","New Zealand"],"other_name":["hybrid fuchsia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Fuchsia hybrida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16910,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron lapponicum requires moderate watering, ensuring that the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. These plants do not tolerate drought or excessive dryness, particularly during their active growing season. It's important to water them deeply each time, allowing the water to reach the root zone, and then let the top few inches of soil dry out before watering again. Be cautious of overwatering, especially in environments with poor drainage, as this can lead to root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain a stable environment for the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron lapponicum thrives in partial shade conditions, where it receives filtered sunlight or dappled shade. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, prolonged exposure to strong, direct sunlight can scorch the leaves and stress the plant. Providing protection from harsh afternoon sun, particularly in hotter climates, is ideal. If grown in very shady areas, it may not bloom as prolifically, so balance is key. Planting it in an area where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade usually works best to sustain its growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron lapponicum should be done sparingly. Light pruning can be performed immediately after the flowering period to maintain the shape and remove any spent blooms or dead branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as this plant does not respond well to severe cuts. It's best to selectively prune branches to open up the plant, improving air circulation and allowing light to penetrate throughout. Avoid pruning late in the season as this can interfere with bud formation for the next bloom cycle. Proper pruning will help maintain a neat appearance and promote healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lapland Azalea","description":"Rhododendron lapponicum (Lapland rosebay, 高山杜鹃) is a rhododendron species found in subarctic regions around the world, where it grows at altitudes ranging from sea level to 1900 meters. It is a shrub that grows to 0.2–0.45 m in height, with leaves that are oblong-elliptic or ovate-elliptic to oblong-obovate, 0.4–1.5 by 0.2–0.5 cm in size. Flowers are reddish or purple.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Lapland Azalea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Bud blast"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron lapponicum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17407,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythrina americana, commonly known as the coral tree, prefers well-drained soil and doesn't require excessively frequent watering. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, from spring to early fall, water every 7-10 days depending on the climate; in hotter regions, more frequent watering might be necessary. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the soil from becoming completely dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythrina americana thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish. This exposure ensures vibrant blooms and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight might lead to sparse blooming and leggy growth. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. Ensure the plant is positioned in a spot that receives ample sunlight throughout the day for optimal performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Erythrina americana in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. This plant benefits from annual pruning to maintain shape, remove any dead or diseased branches, and encourage vigorous blooming. Focus on clearing out old, crossing branches and thinning the canopy to improve air circulation. Be cautious when pruning, as Erythrina species often have thorns or spines. Use sharp, clean tools to make clean cuts just above a bud or lateral branch to promote healthy new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American Coral Tree","description":"Erythrina America, (coral tree or colorines), is a flowering plant of the genus Erythrina which is native to Mexico. It's important to water these plants regularly during their growing season, ensuring the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. However, once established, Phlox nana becomes drought-tolerant and should only need supplemental watering during extended periods of dry weather. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, especially in humid conditions. Always water at the base to keep the foliage dry and minimize the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox nana thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, plant Phlox nana where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the foliage from scorching and help maintain soil moisture. While it can tolerate partial shade, the blooming may not be as prolific, and the plant might become leggier. Providing the right balance of sunlight ensures healthy, vigorous growth and a spectacular display of flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox nana is essential to encourage bushier growth and more prolific blooming. Begin by removing dead or damaged stems and spent flowers throughout the growing season to maintain a tidy appearance and redirect energy into new growth. In late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, cut back the previous year's stems to about six inches above the ground. This helps rejuvenate the plant and improve air circulation, reducing the risk of mildew and pest infestations. Regular deadheading can also prolong the blooming period."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Santa Fe phlox","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Santa Fe phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Phlox nana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once matured, it is best to water this plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. It can tolerate partial sun but may not produce as vibrant fall foliage. While it can adapt to various light conditions, for the best health and color display, ensure it receives plenty of sunlight. This characteristic makes it an excellent choice for sunny, dry landscapes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhus lanceolata is generally minimal but can be done to shape the plant or control its size. If necessary, thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation within the plant. Since it can spread by suckers, some of these can be removed to prevent the plant from becoming too large or invasive in its growing area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Prairie flameleaf sumac","description":"Rhus lanceolata, the prairie sumac, is a plant species native to Texas, Oklahoma, Arizona, New Mexico, and the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo León and Tamaulipas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Prairie flameleaf sumac"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rhus lanceolata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

                    I will provide you with JSON-formatted plant data in English.

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16122,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calophyllum inophyllum, also known as the beach mahogany or tamanu tree, is fairly drought-tolerant once established but benefits from regular watering to help it thrive, especially during dry spells. It prefers well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. When first planting, water deeply and consistently to help the roots establish. Once mature, it requires less frequent waterings, and rainfall is often sufficient. In dry regions or periods, water every 1-2 weeks, ensuring the soil dries out slightly between waterings. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calophyllum inophyllum thrives best in full sun locations, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, providing full sun will enhance its flowering and fruiting performance. In shaded conditions, the tree may grow slower and develop a less uniform canopy. Planting this tree in an open area where it can get unobstructed sunlight will ensure the best results. Additionally, its tolerance to coastal conditions makes it ideal for coastal gardens where sunlight is abundant and salty air is present."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Calophyllum inophyllum is essential to maintain its shape and promote a healthier tree. Prune young trees to encourage a strong, central leader and eliminate any weak or crossing branches. Older trees benefit from the removal of dead, diseased, or damaged wood to reduce pest and disease problems. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring when the tree is dormant. Avoid heavy pruning, which can stress the tree, instead focus on light, corrective cuts. Regular pruning also maintains airflow through the canopy, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alexandrian Laurel","description":"Calophyllum inophyllum is a large evergreen, commonly called Alexandrian laurel balltree, beach calophyllum, beach touriga, beautyleaf, Borneo-mahogany, Indian doomba oiltree, Indian-laurel, laurelwood, red poon, satin touriga, and tacamahac-tree. It is native from East Africa, southern coastal India to Malesia and Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Winter","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Australia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["Alexandrian Laurel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Calophyllum inophyllum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16612,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lyonia fruticosa, commonly known as the coastal plain staggerbush, prefers well-drained, slightly acidic soils and is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water young plants regularly until they are established, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. Mature plants should be watered sparingly, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it is essential to provide them with a well-drained location and to withhold water during rainy periods. Adjust the frequency of watering based on seasonal rainfall and temperature changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lyonia fruticosa thrives in full sunlight to partial shade conditions. It ideally prefers locations where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, it can also tolerate light shade, especially in hotter climates where some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. In areas with intense sun exposure, providing some filtered shade during the hottest parts of the day will help the plant maintain its vigor and lush appearance. The plant's location should be selected based on these sunlight needs to ensure healthy, robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lyonia fruticosa is generally unnecessary except to maintain its shape or remove dead or damaged branches. If pruning is desired, it should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts at the base of overgrown stems or just above a leaf node or lateral branch for shaping purposes. Regularly remove any suckers or unwanted growth to control its spread. Light pruning can encourage bushier growth and help maintain a tidy appearance in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"coastal plain staggerbush","description":"Lyonia fruticosa, the poor-grub or coastal plain staggerbush, is a plant species native to the US states of Florida, southern Georgia and the extreme southern part of South Carolina. It grows in pine woodlands and shrub bogs at elevations less than 100 meters (333 feet).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["coastal plain staggerbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lyonia fruticosa"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
